fieldData.summary: To mark the 20th anniversary of its fight against poverty, the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) in collaboration with Community Jameel, organised a two-day symposium at the Collège de France in Paris. The event, titled 'Science and Fighting Poverty: How far we've come in 20 years and what's next?', convened the Nobel-prize winning co-founders and directors of J-PAL, Esther Duflo and Abhijit Banerjee, along with researchers, policy makers, social work pioneers, financiers and the general public to discuss the role of scientific research in shaping development and social policy to alleviate poverty in different settings and contexts. Sessions included those focused on J-PAL's efforts in Europe, notably its initiatives in France and Spain, as well as a session shared by director of Community Jameel, George Richards, on its work across the continent through the European Social Inclusion Initiative.
fieldData.name: The Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) hosts a symposium in Paris to celebrate its 20th anniversary
fieldData.arabic-title: معمل عبداللطيف جميل لمكافحة الفقر (J-PAL) يستضيف ندوة في باريس احتفالاً بمرور 20 عاماً على انطلاق مسيرته

fieldData.summary: Esther Duflo, co-founder and co-director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL), as well as co-laureate of the 2019 Nobel Prize in Economics, is an economist known for her focus on poverty reduction through on-the-ground randomised control trials in developing countries. She believes that large projects disconnected from reality are not the solution. Her research has positively impacted the lives of more than 600 million people. In an interview with Le Monde, she discussed her work and experiences, emphasising that there is no one formula to make a country prosperous. She has previously advised former U.S. President Barack Obama and has dedicated her career to finding effective ways to alleviate poverty.
fieldData.name: Esther Duflo, Prix Nobel d’économie: « Il n’existe pas de formule pour rendre un pays prospère »
fieldData.arabic-title: إستير دوفلو، الحائزة على جائزة نوبل في الاقتصاد: "لا يوجد صيغة لجعل بلد مزدهرًا"
fieldData.thumbnail-alt-text: Esther Duflo

fieldData.summary: To mark its 20th anniversary, the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL), in collaboration with Community Jameel, organised a two-day symposium at the Collège de France in Paris which convened co-founders and co-directors of J-PAL, Esther Duflo and Abhijit Banerjee, alongside researchers, policy makers, social work pioneers, funders and the general public to discuss the role of scientific research outputs in shaping development and social policy aimed at poverty alleviation in different settings and contexts. During the course of the two days, the symposium focused on the efforts of J-PAL in Europe, and in particular on its initiatives in France and Spain, as well as its work across the continent through the European Social Inclusion Initiative. It also hosted a special forum to discuss the current challenges that stand in the way of poverty eradication efforts around the world and the role of research in providing innovative development solutions.
fieldData.name: The Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab hosts a seminar in Paris
fieldData.arabic-title: معمل عبداللطيف جميل لمكافحة الفقر (J-PAL) يستضيف ندوة في باريس
fieldData.thumbnail-alt-text: In their closing remark at J-PAL's 20th anniversary colloquium, Rémy Rioux, chief executive of Agence Française de Développement, discusses the need for innovation in development.

fieldData.summary: The Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) and Community Jameel held a two-day colloquium at the Collège de France in Paris on 22-23 June, marking 20 years of J-PAL's work in the fight against poverty. The colloquium, entitled 'Science and the fight against poverty: what progress has been made in 20 years and what are the prospects for the future?' brought together J-PAL co-founders and co-directors Esther Duflo and Abhijit Banerjee, alongside researchers, policymakers, social innovators, funders and the general public to explore the role of evidence in shaping development and social policy to alleviate poverty across different contexts. The event aimed to pave the way for informed policymaking that leverages rigorous research and continue to build on J-PAL’s work in ensuring that policies developed and implemented at a global scale can maximise their impact.
fieldData.name: J-PAL hosts colloquium in Paris in celebration of 20 years of fighting against poverty
fieldData.arabic-title: J-PAL يستضيف ندوة في باريس للاحتفال بمرور 20 عامًا على محاربة الفقر
fieldData.thumbnail-alt-text: J-PAL convened researchers, policymakers, social innovators, funders and the general public at the Collège de France on 22-23 June to explore the role of evidence in shaping development and social policy to alleviate poverty across different contexts.

fieldData.summary: The Cultural Development Fund of Egypt and The Prince’s Foundation School of Traditional Arts announced the open call to apply for a diploma at the Jameel House of Traditional Arts in Cairo, in what will be the 15th cohort of the traditional craft and arts programme. Located in Fustat in historic Cairo, the Jameel House was launched in 2009 and is a collaboration between The Prince’s Foundation School of Traditional Arts, Community Jameel, and the Cultural Development Fund of Egypt. With a mission to preserve and champion Egypt’s oldest crafts, the Jameel House accepts around 20 students annually on a two-year training programme to study the disciplines of carpentry, wood veneer, stained glass, copper and ceramics. The programme was developed and delivered by The Prince’s Foundation School according to the same principles and standards as the courses at the London campus. Applications are now open and remain open until 24 August 2023.
fieldData.name: All you need to know about the Jameel House open call for its 15th diploma programme
fieldData.arabic-title: كل ما تريد معرفته عن برنامج بيت جميل بعد فتح باب التقدم للدفعة 15
fieldData.thumbnail-alt-text: The Jameel House of Traditional Arts in Fustat, Historic Cairo accepts 20 students annually to train in a two-year training programme in traditional Islamic arts and crafts.

fieldData.summary: At the height of the Summit for a New Global Financing Pact, the co-founder and co-director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) and winner of the 2019 Nobel Prize in Economics, Esther Duflo, hosted a two-day symposium to mark the 20th year of J-PAL's fight to alleviate global poverty at the Collège de France in Paris. Esther took the opportunity to call for an overhaul of social policy and international solidarity, made necessary by the pandemic, the war in Ukraine and global warming which have pushed millions of people into poverty in low-income countries. Her principle, implemented by J-PAL, is to evaluate public policies using quantitative methods and field experience to encourage evidence-based policy decisions.
fieldData.arabic-title: ممول العقد مونديال: جائزة جائزة نوبل إستر دوفلو أووكس "لا ليسون" تدفع ثرواتها
fieldData.name: Pacte financier mondial : « la leçon » du prix Nobel Esther Duflo aux pays riches
fieldData.thumbnail-alt-text: Esther Duflo addressed attendees, which included researchers, policymakers and financiers, at the J-PAL 20th anniversary colloquium at the Collège de France, Paris.

fieldData.arabic-title: مع BioAutoMATED ، يمكن الآن لكل عالم أحياء استخدام التعلم الآلي
fieldData.summary: Scientists generate massive amounts of data today, thanks to the falling costs of sequencing technology and the increasing amount of available computing power. But parsing through large volumes of data to uncover useful information is like searching for a needle in a haystack. Machine learning (ML) and other artificial intelligence (AI) tools can dramatically speed up the process of data analysis, but most ML tools are difficult for non-ML experts to access and use. Researchers at the MIT Jameel Clinic, the epicentre of health care and AI at MIT, have designed a comprehensive automated ML (AutoML) platform for biologists with little to no ML experience. The platform, called BioAutoMATED, can use sequences of nucleic acids, peptides, or glycans as input data, and its performance is comparable to other AutoML platforms while requiring minimal user input. The platform is described in a new paper co-authored by Jim Collins, Jameel Clinic's life sciences faculty lead, and is available to download from GitHub.
fieldData.name: With BioAutoMATED, now every biologist can use machine learning
fieldData.thumbnail-alt-text: Lines of machine learning code overlaid on molecules.

fieldData.name: J-PAL South Asia: Evidence-informed policy
fieldData.arabic-title: J-PAL جنوب آسيا السياسة المستنيرة بالأدلة
fieldData.summary:
The Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab South Asia (J-PAL SA), under the leadership of executive director, Shobhini Mukerji, collaborates with state governments in India to evaluate policies and help them adopt new, evidence-informed approaches to policymaking. The Chandler Foundation, an international foundation supporting social investments and partnerships to catalyse economic opportunity, is resourcing J-PAL SA to launch a Governance Unit, which will strengthen how the organisation equips leaders and supports governments to adapt evidence-informed policymaking. By doing so, The Chandler Foundation looks to support J-PAL SA as it works with governments to improve people’s lives and implement mechanisms, using technology, accountability and better execution, to strengthen governance in India.

‍
fieldData.thumbnail-alt-text: The Chandler Foundation is resourcing J-PAL SA to launch a Governance Unit, which will strengthen how the organisation equips leaders and supports governments to adapt evidence-informed policymaking.

fieldData.summary:
Egypt's Cultural Development Fund and the Prince's Foundation School of Traditional Arts in London has announced the open call to apply for the 15th annual Jameel House of Traditional Arts in Cairo diploma programme.

Opened in 2009 in Fustat, historic Cairo, the Jameel House is a collaboration between The Prince’s Foundation School of Traditional Arts, Community Jameel, and the Cultural Development Fund of Egypt, with a mission to preserve and champion Egypt’s oldest crafts. Each year, the Jameel House diploma trains a cohort of students over a two-year period in traditional crafts such as carpentry, wood veneer, stained glass, copper and ceramics. Applications for the 15th open call remain open until 23 August 2023.
fieldData.name: Open call for applications for the 15th annual Jameel House of Traditional Arts in Cairo programme
fieldData.arabic-title: صندوق التنمية الثقافية: فتح باب التقدم للدفعة 15 من برنامج "بيت جميل للحرف التقليدية"
fieldData.thumbnail-alt-text: A second year diploma student at the Jameel House of Traditional Arts in Cairo works on their graduation metalwork project.

fieldData.summary: The Cultural Development Fund of Egypt and The Prince's Foundation School of Traditional Arts in London has announced the open call to apply for the Jameel House of Traditional Arts in Cairo diploma programme. The Jameel House was launched in 2009 and is a collaboration between The Prince’s Foundation School of Traditional Arts, Community Jameel, and the Cultural Development Fund of Egypt. Now in its 15th year, the diploma programme at the Jameel House, based in Fustat, historic Cairo, trains students over a period of two years in traditional Islamic craft techniques and disciplines including wood veneer, stained glass, copper and ceramics. The programme is developed and delivered by The Prince’s Foundation School according to the same principles and standards as the courses at the London campus. Applications are open until 24 August 2023.
fieldData.name: Egypt's Cultural Development Fund announces 15th open call for the Jameel House programme
fieldData.arabic-title: التنمية الثقافية يفتح باب التقدم للدفعة 15 من برنامج «بيت جميل»

fieldData.summary: The world has already warmed an average of nearly 1.2 degrees Celsius since the mid-1800s, according to a report by global climate scientists released in June 2023, unleashing a series of extreme weather events. Hardest hit are the most vulnerable people and the world's poorest countries, who have done little to contribute to the fossil fuel-driven rise in temperatures. According to this trend, climate change driven by rich countries will cause mortality among poor nations to increase, the co-founder and co-director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) and Nobel-prize-winning economist Esther Duflo warned in an interview with AFP, calling for a global tax ahead of French president Emmanuel Macron's summit for a new global financing pact, held in Paris on 22 June 2023.
fieldData.name: Nobel-winning economist calls for climate tax as carbon costs lives
fieldData.arabic-title: خبير اقتصادي حائز على جائزة نوبل يدعو إلى فرض ضريبة مناخية لأن الكربون يكلف الأرواح
fieldData.thumbnail-alt-text: Co-founder and co-director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL), Esther Duflo, photographed in Paris on 20 June 2023 ahead of J-PAL's 20th anniversary and President Macron's summit for a new financing pact to combat climate change.

fieldData.summary:
The 2023 migration summit hosted by the MIT Jameel World Education Lab (J-WEL)'s MIT Refugee Action Hub (ReACT), Na’amal and Karam Foundation, addressed systemic challenges and opportunities faced by refugee and migrant communities. Welcoming over 2,400 participants from 120 countries, a key focus of the summit was co-creating pathways for learning, livelihood and dignity.

Key discussions revolved around challenges in higher education, workforce development, digital livelihoods, evidence and research. Sessions also highlighted the stereotypes and misconceptions about displaced and migrant populations, stressing their potential to enhance productivity, sociocultural, and economic development in communities. The opening keynote was by Omar Alshogre, a Syrian refugee and human rights advocate. His speech focused on education, trauma and the power of storytelling.

The summit also provided a platform for organisations to share their experiences and build collaborations to support displaced communities. International aid organisations like the UN Refugee Agency (UNHCR), the International Organisation For Migration (IOM) and the International Rescue Committee (IRC) were present.
fieldData.name: J-WEL migration summit 2023 advances global dialogue on migration
fieldData.arabic-title: قمة J-WEL للهجرة 2023 تعزز الحوار العالمي حول الهجرة

fieldData.name: Esther Duflo : "On assiste depuis 2019 à une globalisation des problèmes auxquels font face les plus pauvres"
fieldData.arabic-title: إستر دوفلو: "منذ 2019 شهدنا عولمة المشاكل التي تواجه الأشد فقرا"
fieldData.summary: Esther Duflo, co-founder and co-director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL), and the 2019 Nobel laureate in economics, discusses the global challenges faced by the world's poorest since 2019. Despite positive progress in reducing extreme poverty and maternal and infant mortality over the past 30 years, recent events like the COVID-19 crisis and the Ukraine war have slowed poverty reduction. Duflo emphasises the globalisation of problems for the poor, while countries tend to close themselves off from global trade opportunities. She cautions that measuring poverty takes time, and there has been a setback that is difficult to quantify. Her research calls for innovative approaches to address the complex issues of poverty worldwide.
fieldData.thumbnail-alt-text: A paper cup on a street pavement containing some coins.

fieldData.summary:
The Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab Middle East and North Africa (J-PAL MENA) at the American University in Cairo (AUC) has announced the selection of its first cohort of MENA Scholars Fellowship. Supported by Community Jameel and the Sawiris Foundation for Social Development, the fellowship provides scholars with a two-year stipend to support their time participating in fellowship program activities. These activities include working on a randomised evaluation, with mentorship and guidance from J-PAL affiliated professors, becoming a member of the worldwide network of fellows from other J-PAL fellowships, enrolling in MIT’s MicroMasters Program in Data, Economics and Development Policy, attending training sessions and workshops from J-PAL MENA staff and presenting in J-PAL MENA policy events in the region. Out of a large pool of applicants, six fellows were selected from Egypt, Morocco, Saudi Arabia and Jordan.

‍
fieldData.name: New J-PAL fellowship helps researchers fight poverty in MENA
fieldData.arabic-title: تساعد زمالة J-PAL الجديدة الباحثين في مكافحة الفقر في منطقة الشرق الأوسط وشمال إفريقيا
fieldData.thumbnail-alt-text: Noha Mostafa, one of the 2023 J-PAL MENA Scholars Fellows, and assistant lecturer in economics at the University of Cairo.

fieldData.summary:
Societies have implemented diverse mechanisms to cultivate progress and advancement, ranging from the market system to the patent system and government funding. However, according to Nobel-prize winning economist Esther Duflo, co-founder and co-director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL), and fellow Nobel laureate Michael Kremer, there is a notable gap in fostering innovations that enhance the delivery of government services, particularly those that cater to the needs of the most vulnerable populations. Unfortunately, investment in such transformative solutions often goes unnoticed.

To address this issue, countries like the United States and France have taken steps to establish public funds dedicated to supporting innovations that directly benefit underprivileged individuals. These social innovation funds embrace an inclusive, multi-tiered, and evidence-based approach.
fieldData.name: Throwing good money after good
fieldData.arabic-title: رمي المال الجيد بعد الخير
fieldData.thumbnail-alt-text: The United States and France have now established public funds that invest in innovations addressing the needs of poor people, such as innovations to improve the delivery of government services.

fieldData.summary: A public installation originally launched by Cooking Sections during the 17th Istanbul Biennial in 2022, 'Wallowland (Çamuralem)' has reopened in a new location in the Kurtuluş neighborhood of Istanbul. The installation creatively reimagines a muhallebici, a shop known for buffalo milk desserts, as a tribute to the water buffalos and their herders who have traditionally surrounded the city. The installation is an integral part of a long-term research project by CLIMAVORE x Jameel at the Royal College of Art in London, focusing on the preservation of Istanbul's wetlands and the water buffalo that have inhabited them for centuries. Buffalo milk holds significant historical and cultural importance in Turkish cuisine, relying on the protection of wetlands. With increasing urbanisation encroaching upon the wetlands, 'Wallowland' aims to support this unique ecosystem and its rich culinary traditions.
fieldData.name: Muhallebici shop to get taste of city’s wetlands
fieldData.arabic-title: متجر موهاليبيشي لتذوق طعم الأراضي الرطبة في المدينة
fieldData.thumbnail-alt-text: Wallowland (Çamuralem) is Cooking Section's reinterpretation of a Muhallebici (buffalo milk dessert shop) recently opened in Istanbul's Kurtulus neighbourhood.

fieldData.summary: Researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) and the Abdul Latif Jameel Water and Food Systems Lab (J-WAFS) at MIT have developed a 'super absorbent' hydrogel that can extract a record amount of moisture from the air, even in desert-like conditions. The material, made from hydrogel infused with lithium chloride, can swell to make room for more moisture as it absorbs water vapor. Even in very dry conditions with 30 percent relative humidity, the material can pull vapour from the air and hold the moisture without leaking. This transparent, rubbery material has the potential to be used as a passive water harvester in drought-prone regions, where it continuously absorbs vapour that can be condensed into drinking water. Another use is on air conditioning units to improve efficiency and act as a dehumidifier. The material's low cost and high performance make it a promising solution for water scarcity and energy efficiency challenges. The research was led by Carlos Díaz-Marin, an MIT graduate student and member of the Device Research Lab. A study co-authored by J-WAFS principal investigator, Evelyn Wang, was published in a paper in Advanced Materials.
fieldData.name: This salty gel could harvest water from desert air
fieldData.arabic-title: يمكن لهذا الهلام المالح أن يجمع الماء من هواء الصحراء

fieldData.summary: In 1993, the United States' National Institutes of Health Revitalisation Act mandated the inclusion of 'women and minorities' in clinical trials in a bid to reduce health disparities. However, to date, gender disparities in clinical trials persist, as does a male-centric model of medicine which is still applied women, despite the physiological differences between the sexes. According to a study into mental health conducted in Tamil Nadu by co-founders and co-directors of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL), Abhijit Banerjee and Esther Duflo, more women than men aged 61-70 displayed symptoms indicating a high likelihood of depression. Despite this acknowledgement, studies repeatedly demonstrate that women are less likely to receive appropriate medications, diagnostic tests and clinical procedures for mental health issues across high-, middle- and low-income countries. It is time for policy intervention in the space of gender-specific research in medicine, with India’s G20 presidency an ideal time to highlight this issue.
fieldData.name: Male-centric medicine is affecting women’s health
fieldData.arabic-title: يؤثر الطب الذي يركز على الذكور على صحة المرأة
fieldData.thumbnail-alt-text: The gender disparity in clinical trials has wide implications on women's diagnosis, treatment and its effectiveness.

fieldData.summary: The Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab Middle East and North Africa (J-PAL MENA) at the American University in Cairo (AUC) has announced the selection of the first cohort of its MENA Scholars Fellowship. Supported by Community Jameel and the Sawiris Foundation for Social Development, the new fellowship seeks to build a community of regional researchers with technical and hands-on experience in designing and conducting randomised evaluations of poverty reduction programmes. Following its launch in 2022, the fellowship received an overwhelming response with a highly competitive pool of applications from across the MENA region. After a rigorous selection process, six outstanding scholars from Egypt, Jordan, Saudi Arabia and Morocco were chosen: Eman Elish, Noha Mostafa, Nouf Abushehab, Reem Alsukait, Yasmine Hassan and Zakaria Mansouri.
fieldData.name: Selection of the first J-PAL MENA Scholars at the American University in Cairo
fieldData.arabic-title: اختيار أول دفعة من ” زمالة باحثي مكافحة الفقر ” بالجامعة الأمريكية بالقاهرة

fieldData.summary: One of the risks technology and healthcare experts perceive in the use of artificial intelligence (AI) is that people can ascribe too much wisdom to AI applications and might forgo other trusted sources of information. As society realises the drawbacks of adopting AI in certain areas of work and life, there remain trusted and robust AI systems within the medical sector which can help optimise and streamline healthcare and research. One example is an AI tool for assessing lung cancer risk developed by scientists at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Jameel Clinic. Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer death globally, and the tool, Sybil, can help predict the risk of developing lung cancer up to six years in advance.
fieldData.name: Healthy approach to AI
fieldData.arabic-title: نهج صحي للذكاء الاصطناعي
fieldData.thumbnail-alt-text: Tested and trusted AI systems such as MIT Jameel Clinic's Sybil are helping to assess lung cancer risk, the leading cause of cancer death.

Supported by Community Jameel and the Sawiris Foundation for Social Development, the MENA Scholars Fellowship will seek to build a community of regional researchers with technical and hands-on experience in designing and conducting randomised evaluations of poverty reduction programmes.

fieldData.summary: A new book from Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) professors Damon Acemoğlu and Simon Johnson, 'Power and progress: Our thousand-year struggle over technology and prosperity', challenges whether technology equates to progress that is truly beneficial to humankind. Co-founders and co-directors of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) at MIT, Esther Duflo and Abhijit Banerjee, commented on the authors' arguments: "Technology is not destiny, nothing is preordained. Humans, despite their imperfect institutions and often-contradictory impulses, remain in the driver’s seat. It is still our job to determine whether the vehicles we build are heading toward justice or down the cliff. In this age of relentless automation and seemingly unstoppable consolidation of power and wealth, 'Power and progress' is an essential reminder that we can, and must, take back control".
fieldData.name: Repurpose technology for public good, not just private profit
fieldData.arabic-title: أعد استخدام التكنولوجيا للصالح العام ، وليس فقط الربح الخاص

fieldData.summary: Six outstanding young researchers from across the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region have been selected by the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) MENA office at the American University in Cairo (AUC) to take a Nobel Prize-winning approach to alleviating poverty in the Middle East and North Africa with the support of a new fellowship. With support from Community Jameel and the Sawiris Foundation for Social Development, the new fellowship supports six scholars this year from Egypt, Jordan, Saudi Arabia and Morocco as they participate in J-PAL programme activities including working on a randomised evaluation, with mentorship and guidance from J-PAL affiliated professors, becoming a member of the worldwide J-PAL fellowship network, enrolling in the Massachusetts Institute of Technology’s MicroMasters programme in data, economics and development policy, attending training sessions and workshops from J-PAL MENA staff and presenting in J-PAL MENA policy events in the region.

fieldData.summary: Wallowland (Çamuralem), a Muhallebicisi (buffalo milk dessert shop) originally designed by Cooking Sections, as one of the participants in the 17th Istanbul Biennial in 2022, has reopened its doors at a new location in Istanbul, hosted by Ek Biç Ye İç. The reopening is part of a long-term research project conducted by CLIMAVORE x Jameel at the Royal College of Art in London (RCA) focusing on the preservation of wetlands, which have been the home and habitat of Istanbul's buffalo for centuries. At the opening of the pudding shop in Kurtuluş, Istanbul, Cooking Sections founders Daniel Pascual Fernández and Alon Schwabe, alongside Anadolu Meadows, Yasemin Kireç and Evrim Çoksözler, talked about wetlands and biodiversity in and around Istanbul and shared the current outputs of their research.

fieldData.excerpt:
Products made from polymers — ranging from plastic bags to clothing to cookware to electronics — provide many comforts and support today’s standard of living, but since they do not decompose easily, they pose long-term environmental challenges. Developing polymers, a large class of materials, with a more sustainable life cycle is a critical step in making progress toward a green economy and addressing this piece of the global climate change crisis. The development of biodegradable polymers, however, remains limited by current biodegradation testing methods.

To address this limitation, a team of MIT researchers led by Bradley D. Olsen, the Alexander and I. Michael Kasser (1960) Professor in the Department of Chemical Engineering, has developed an expansive biodegradation dataset to help determine whether or not a polymer is biodegradable.

Their findings were recently published in The Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences (PNAS), a peer reviewed journal of the National Academy of Sciences (NAS), in a paper titled "High-Throughput Experimentation for Discovery of Biodegradable Polyesters." The MIT team is led by Olsen and PhD candidates Katharina A. Fransen and Sarah H. M. Av-Ron, and also includes postdoc Dylan J. Walsh and undergraduate students Tess R. Buchanan, Dechen T. Rota, and Lana Van Note.
fieldData.summary:
Bradley Olsen, professor of chemical engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) and principal investigator at the Abdul Latif Jameel Water and Food Systems Lab (J-WAFS) leads researchers, including Katharina Fransen, 2022 J-WAFS fellow, in the development of an expansive dataset to determine biodegradable polymers.

Bradley says, “Despite polymer waste being a known and significant contributor to the climate crisis, the study of polymer biodegradation has been limited to a small number of polymers because current biodegradation testing methods are time- and resource-intensive. This limited scope slows new material innovation, so we are working to open that up to a much broader portfolio of materials.”
fieldData.name: Advancing material innovation to address the polymer waste crisis
fieldData.thumbnail-alt-text: Images of a fast-propagating clear-zone, captured in eight-hour intervals
fieldData.arabic-title: تطوير ابتكار المواد لمعالجة أزمة نفايات البوليمر

fieldData.summary: Set up in 2018, the Infected Blood Inquiry examines the circumstances in which treatment and blood transfusions provided by the UK national health services were contaminated with HIV and hepatitis between 1970 and 1991. The Inquiry commissioned a number of reports about the impact of infections consequent to the use of infected blood and blood products, including from researchers at the Jameel Institute at Imperial College London. Professor Katharina Hauck, deputy director, Jameel Institute and lead, Jameel Institute-Kenneth C Griffin Initiative for Economics of Pandemic Preparedness, and her team estimated three impacts: healthcare and social care costs to the NHS and individuals, income loss to the infected and their informal carers, and lost health due to earlier death and ill-health. The impacts were estimated for both Hepatitis C and HIV for modelled life trajectories between 1970 and 2021.
fieldData.name: Jameel Institute experts at Imperial provide economic perspective to the Infected Blood Inquiry
fieldData.arabic-title: يقدم الخبراء الإمبراطوريون منظورًا اقتصاديًا للاستعلام عن الدم المصاب
fieldData.thumbnail-alt-text: Jameel Institute at Imperial researchers have contributed to an independent inquiry looking at the impacts on UK patients who were given infected blood products.

fieldData.summary:
Abdul Latif Jameel Water and Food Systems Lab (J-WAFS) 2023 Solutions Grant recipient and Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) associate professor of metallurgy, Cem Tasan discusses his background and current work in metallurgy, unexpected results in life and in the lab and embracing uncertainty.

“As they say, science is like taking a walk in the hills,” Tasan says. “You see the mountain far away, and that’s where you want to go, but as you head toward it, you see a beautiful flower on a different pathway, so you check that out. That happens so often to [my group]. It’s exciting.”
fieldData.name: Embracing life's surprises
fieldData.thumbnail-alt-text: Photograph of Cem Tasan
fieldData.arabic-title: احتضان مفاجآت الحياة
fieldData.excerpt:
Experiments often yield unexpected results. In research and in life, MIT Associate Professor Cem Tasan has learned to embrace that uncertainty.

“Very often we start with an idea or a hypothesis, and to test that idea we design experiments, and when we run the experiments, we see something totally different,” says Tasan, the newly tenured Thomas B. King Associate Professor of Metallurgy.

Tasan has used those surprises to explore the boundaries of metallurgy and solid mechanics, gleaning new insights into how metals break and deform, and designing new kinds of damage-resistant alloys.

An ancient civilization steeped in rich cultural heritage, a beacon of history imbued with echoes of grandeur in every crevice of its streets, Egypt has always been a majestic melting pot of artistic and intellectual creativity, resulting in a distinct alluring amalgamation of cultures and histories exclusive only to its people.

In the spirit of showcasing and preserving Egypt’s cultural heritage and connecting young Egyptians to their roots, these seven programs offer a plethora of unique culturally-dense experiences to learn and engage with Egypt's rich legacy and modern culture.
fieldData.summary: The Jameel House of Traditional Arts in Cairo is counted among the top activities and programmes offered in Cairo that allow participants to embrace Egyptian culture. The call for applications for the new cohort of two-year scholars closes on 30 August 2023.
fieldData.name: 7 programmes that will let you embrace Egyptian culture
fieldData.thumbnail-alt-text: Jameel House of Traditional Arts in Cairo
fieldData.arabic-title: 7 برامج ستتيح لك احتضان الثقافة المصرية

fieldData.excerpt:
He announced the opening of applications for the 15th batch of the scholarship offered free of charge, in cooperation with the Prince Charles Foundation School of Traditional Arts and the Cultural Development Fund in Egypt, to teach traditional crafts and arts.

Applications for the scholarship and portfolio will start from today, June 7, and continue until August 31, 2023, at the Jameel House of Traditional Arts headquarters in the Fustat Center for Traditional Crafts from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m., except Friday and Saturday, or you can apply through the link on your Instagram page.

The scholarship aims to graduate the designer and executor through study and practical training for two full years. His studies focus on Islamic architecture with its patterns and designs, color harmony, and decoration techniques, as well as practical training in ceramic crafts, woodwork, copperwork, gypsum carving, and various other crafts.
fieldData.summary: The Jameel House of Traditional Arts in Cairo, supported by Community Jameel, The King's Foundation and the Cultural Development Fund in Egypt, opens calls for applications for its two-year scholarship programme in Islamic architecture and traditional arts. The application period runs from 7 June - 31 August 2023.

fieldData.summary: How should schools prepare students to live in a world where the rise of AI-powered tools seems almost inevitable? Should education institutions teach students to code and use AI tools and provide the technology skills training employees seek? Or should students learn to anticipate and mitigate the damage of artificial intelligence? Cynthia Breazeal, dean for digital learning at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where she also oversees the work of the Abdul Latif Jameel World Education Lab, said MIT's initiative on responsible artificial intelligence for social empowerment and education seeks to help schools do both.
fieldData.name: Oye, Alexa, ¿qué deberían aprender los estudiantes sobre la inteligencia artificial?
fieldData.arabic-title: مرحبًا أليكسا ، ما الذي يجب أن يتعلمه الطلاب عن الذكاء الاصطناعي؟
fieldData.thumbnail-alt-text: Students from the Dearborn STEM Academy in Boston, United States listen to instructions during an Amazon-led workshop where they learn how to program Alexa, the company's virtual assistant, on May 18, 2023

fieldData.summary: The Abdul Latif Jameel Water and Food Systems Lab (J-WAFS) is offering travel grants for outstanding Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) graduate students to attend one of two major water sector conferences in 2023: World Water Week in Stockholm and the 'Water and health' conference at the University of North Carolina. Four exceptional graduate students have been selected to attend World Water Week, which convenes academics, non-governmental organisations, industry professionals and government officials to rethink water management. It asks: which ideas, innovations, and governance systems will be needed in a more unstable and water-scarce world? The J-WAFS travel grant for water conferences is supported by Xylem Inc. and GoAigua, both J-WAFS research affiliates and water technology companies. It covers students' travel, registration, accommodation and expenses during the conference.
fieldData.name: J-WAFS announces 2023 Travel Grantees to attend Stockholm World Water Week
fieldData.arabic-title: تعلن معمل معمل عبد اللطيف جميل للأمن الغذائي والمائي (J-WAFS) عن الفائزين بمنح السفر لعام 2023 لحضور أسبوع المياه العالمي في ستوكهولم
fieldData.thumbnail-alt-text: Four outstanding MIT students were selected to receive the J-WAFS Travel Grant to attend the 2023 'World water week' in Sweden.

fieldData.summary: Indian non-profit organisation The/Nudge Institute’s 'End ultra poverty' programme targets the poorest households and provides them with productive asset grants, training and support as well as life skills coaching. The programme follows the graduation approach to poverty alleviation, which, a group of economists including co-founders and co-directors of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) Abhijit Banerjee and Esther Duflo stated in a research paper published in Science, 'targets the poorest members in a village and provides a productive asset grant, training and support, life skills coaching, temporary cash consumption support and typically access to savings accounts and health information or services'. As part of their evaluation, the research group conducted trials in Ethiopia, Ghana, Honduras, India, Pakistan and Peru with 10,495 participants.
fieldData.arabic-title: كيف يساعد نهج التخرج النساء على الخروج من الفقر المدقع
fieldData.name: How the graduation approach is helping women out of ultra-poverty
fieldData.thumbnail-alt-text: A member of the Nudge Institute's 'End ultra poverty' programme standing outside a pig shed managed by her.

fieldData.summary:
Summary

The newspaper Al Sharq Al Awsat interviewed various science, business, non-profit and thought leaders about whether artificial intelligence (AI) will defeat humans or vice versa, and whether or not it will lead to a transformation in all areas of work and human life as we know it.

Perspectives

George Richards, director of Community Jameel, which supports the research of the Jameel Clinic at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) to develop AI tools that can improve global health and wellbeing, said: "Community Jameel is well aware of the potential of AI to achieve improvements in global health".

He emphasised the MIT Jameel Clinic's focus on ensuring that AI tools "reach those with weak resources", adding that "this is the reason we are supporting the Jameel Clinic along with the British charity Wellcome Trust to develop a network of partner hospitals to disseminate these tools".
fieldData.name: Artificial intelligence: Who wins?
fieldData.arabic-title: الذكاء الاصطناعي والإنسان... من يهزم من؟
fieldData.thumbnail-alt-text: Experts from different fields debate how significant AI's transformation of work and human life will really be.

fieldData.summary: Co-founder and co-director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab and food writer Abhijit Banerjee contemplates the origins of koshari, a dish widely considered the national dish of Egypt. Koshari comes from khichdi, an Indian dish gifted from Indian soldiers stationed in Egypt during the first world war which has likewise been labeled by some as the national dish of India. Abhijit considers the nostalgia that immigrants (himself included) feel for the food of their home country, and wonders what comfort and sense of community that these foods can offer diasporas working and living in difficult, uncertain and often unwelcoming conditions.
fieldData.arabic-title: الخيشدي إلى الكشري المصري ، وسحر الأكل وراء الحدود
fieldData.name: Khichdi to Egyptian koshari, and the magic of food beyond borders
fieldData.thumbnail-alt-text: Koshari, an Egyptian dish of a rice and brown lentils, with a tomato sauce, a garnish of browned onions and macaroni, descends from the Indian comfort dish, kichdi.

fieldData.summary: Yale’s Tobin Centre for Economic Policy convened with researchers and state officials to enhance Connecticut’s Medicaid programme. The meeting marked the beginning of a partnership between the State of Connecticut, the Tobin Centre and the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) at MIT to harness evidence-based social science research to improve the local public health system. Specifically, they explored the potential to improve the Medicaid programme through randomised-controlled trials (RCTs), a methodology spearheaded by J-PAL, which uses prospective studies to measure the effectiveness of policy interventions.
fieldData.name: At Yale, scholars and policymakers unite to improve state Medicaid program
fieldData.arabic-title: في جامعة ييل ، يتحد العلماء وصانعو السياسات لتحسين برنامج المعونة الطبية التابع للولاية

fieldData.summary:
Researchers at the MIT Jameel Clinic, the epicentre of AI and healthcare at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, used AI to identify a new antibiotic that can kill Acinetobacter baumannii, a species of bacteria that is often found in hospitals and can lead to pneumonia, meningitis and other serious infections. Researchers Jim Collins and Regina Barzilay of MIT Jameel Clinic in collaboration with researchers from McMaster University authored a study identifying the new drug, named abaucin, from a library of nearly 7,000 potential drug compounds using a machine-learning model. 'This finding further supports the premise that AI can significantly accelerate and expand our search for novel antibiotics', said Collins.

‍
fieldData.name: Using AI, scientists find a drug that could combat drug-resistant infections
fieldData.arabic-title: باستخدام الذكاء الاصطناعي ، وجد العلماء دواءً يمكنه مكافحة العدوى المقاومة للأدوية

fieldData.name: New superbug-killing antibiotic discovered using AI
fieldData.arabic-title: تم اكتشاف مضاد حيوي جديد قاتل للبكتيريا باستخدام الذكاء الاصطناعي
fieldData.summary:
Scientists, with the help of artificial intelligence (AI), have discovered a potent new antibiotic called abaucin that can effectively kill a deadly superbug known as Acinetobacter baumannii.

Jim Collins, the faculty lead of life sciences at the MIT Jameel Clinic, expressed his excitement about using AI to combat problematic pathogens like A. baumannii, saying, 'This finding further supports the premise that AI can significantly accelerate and expand our search for novel antibiotics'.

The experimental antibiotic has shown promising results in treating infected wounds in mice and eliminating A. baumannii samples from patients. This breakthrough highlights the revolutionary potential of AI in science and medicine, offering hope in the fight against antibiotic resistance.
fieldData.thumbnail-alt-text: Halicin

fieldData.summary: Graduates of the inaugural Data, Economics, and Development Policy (DEDP) programme set up by the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) are well on their way to realising their post-graduation endeavours to alleviate global poverty through their work in government, nonprofits, international organisations and research. In this DEDP alumni spotlight, Nouf Abushehab and Brian Daza offer their reflections on the DEDP programme and their current work. Nouf (DEDP 2020), a PhD student at Trinity College Dublin, credits the DEDP programme with helping her transition from her previous work in her home country with the Economic & Social Council of Jordan into development research. Her goal is to contribute to expanding the use of research and evidence in Jordan and the Middle East, and was recently selected for the first cohort of the J-PAL Middle East and North Africa Scholars Fellowship, which supports early career researchers looking to work on randomised evaluations in the region with mentorship from J-PAL affiliates.
fieldData.name: DEDP alumni spotlight: Pursuing research around the world while staying connected to the J-PAL community
fieldData.arabic-title: تسليط الضوء على خريجي DEDP: متابعة البحث في جميع أنحاء العالم مع البقاء على اتصال بمجتمع J-PAL

fieldData.summary:
Verge Genomics, a clinical-stage, tech-enabled biotechnology company using artificial intelligence (AI) and human data to transform drug discovery and development, announced that Emerald Innovations’ wireless digital health technology will be used in its upcoming clinical trials to study a new therapy for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). Emerald's wireless sensors will be used to capture 'objecive' critical patient data in its planned Phase 1b proof-of-concept study of the PIKfyve inhibitor VRG50635, the novel therapeutic for ALS.

Designed by Dina Katabi, principal investigator for the MIT Jameel Clinic and co-founder of Emerald Innovations, the biosensor belongs to a new class of 'invisible' sensors that operate in the background, and extract health metrics by analysing the surrounding radio signals using AI, without requiring patients to use wearable devices or to manually record their experience.

Through the collaboration, Emerald’s wireless digital health sensors will be placed in study participants’ homes to continuously measure key neurological functions affected by ALS, including sleeping, breathing, walking and mobility. Analyses of the Emerald data will be used to assess changes in patients being treated with increasing doses of VRG50635.
fieldData.name: Verge Genomics to incorporate Emerald digital health technology into its ALS phase 1b proof-of-concept clinical trial
fieldData.arabic-title: شركة Verge Genomics تدمج تقنية الصحة الرقمية الزمردية في تجربتها السريرية لإثبات مفهوم ALS - المرحلة 1 ب
fieldData.thumbnail-alt-text: Abstract image of emeralds.

fieldData.summary: The 2nd International Forum on Poverty Reduction, held in Uzbekistan, has concluded, having discussed a wide range of issues and proposals for poverty alleviation in developing countries. Abhijit Banerjee, co-founder and co-director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL), gave an address at the forum, highlighting the progress made by Uzbekistan in terms of domestic poverty reduction despite challenges, including the COVID-19 pandemic, an uncertain global economy, and other destabilizing world events.
fieldData.name: Глобальная борьба с бедностью: опыт Узбекистана обсужден на международном Форуме в Ташкенте

fieldData.summary: A growing body of evidence suggests that creating art, as well as activities like attending a concert or visiting a museum, can benefit mental health. Researchers and scientists such as Susan Magsamen have found that there are simple ways to elevate one's mood with the arts, including by drawing simple stick figures. The method features in Susan's new book, 'Your brains on art: How the arts transform us', co-authored with Dr James Gordon, a psychiatrist and the founder of the Centre for Mind-Body Medicine. Susan is a member of the Jameel Arts & Health Lab steering committee and executive director of the International Arts + Mind Lab at Johns Hopkins University.
fieldData.name: How the arts can benefit your mental health (no talent required)
fieldData.arabic-title: كيف يمكن للفنون أن تفيد صحتك العقلية (لا تتطلب موهبة)

fieldData.summary: A 39 ans, Julia Cagé, professeure à Sciences Po Paris, et Vincent Pons, professeur à Harvard et professeur affilié au Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) du Massachusetts Institute of Technology, sont les lauréats, ex aequo, de cette 24ᵉ édition du prix du meilleur jeune économiste créé en 2000 par « Le Monde » et le Cercle des économistes. Le prix est l’occasion de vérifier si les agendas de recherche des candidats recouvrent les interrogations les plus fortes quant aux dérèglements des économies et s’ils tracent des pistes utiles. Avec les deux lauréats ex aequo, le jury a couronné cette année des travaux qui portent sur la crise de la démocratie.
fieldData.name: Julia Cagé et Vincent Pons, Prix du meilleur jeune économiste 2023
fieldData.arabic-title: جوليا كاجيه وفينسنت بونس ، جائزة أفضل عالم اقتصادي شاب لعام 2023

fieldData.summary: Events during Earth Month at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) spanned a vast range of ideas and approaches to tackling the climate crisis, many of which are researched and developed inside the Abdul Latif Jameel Water and Food Systems Lab (J-WAFS). Students and post-doctoral students at the Lab's 2023 poster sessions presented innovations to mitigate and adapt to climate change including: a mathematical tool for managing reliability in wind powered systems; 3D observations to assess the performance of a liquid-infused filter for environmental pollutants; techniques using nuclear magnetic resonance to monitor soil carbon levels at large scale, which may help to validate sustainable agricultural practices; and a design for an energy-efficient and affordable irrigation system for farmers with limited resources.
fieldData.name: Six ways MIT is taking action on climate
fieldData.arabic-title: ست طرق يتخذ معهد ماساتشوستس للتكنولوجيا إجراءات بشأن المناخ

fieldData.summary: Established in 1989, the Jameel Centre provided a focal point for progressive management education and training in the Middle East. It has since evolved into a space that helps shape Egypt’s tech-immersed entrepreneurial landscape as a core part of The GrEEK Campus, Cairo’s first technology and innovation park established at the former AUC site in 2013. In a new photo essay commissioned by Community Jameel, Cairo-based photographer Ebrahim Bahaa-Eldin captures the unique and flexible architectural design of the Jameel Centre, which continues to adapt and evolve along with its community of entrepreneurs, as well as the surrounding environment and culture.
fieldData.name: A Cairo cornerstone: The Jameel Centre, Downtown Cairo's Mamluk-inspired 1980s architectural masterpiece
fieldData.arabic-title: حجر الزاوية في القاهرة: مركز جميل ، تحفة معمارية مستوحاة من الثمانينيات من القرن الماضي في وسط القاهرة.

fieldData.summary: Wellcome has announced a USD 2.3 million grant to Data.org in support of data skills education, training and workforce development in India. The grant will fund the India Data Capacity Accelerator—one of three programmes in the Data.org network—and enable the design and rollout of learning programmes to create and engage top data talent to work in the Indian social sector. Local partners include the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab, Ashoka University, Birla Institute of Technology and Science, Pilani and Indraprastha Institute of Information Technology Delhi.
fieldData.name: Wellcome awards USD 2.3 million for data skills education in India
fieldData.arabic-title: تمنح Wellcome 2.3 مليون دولار لتعليم مهارات البيانات في الهند

fieldData.summary:
The Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) has impacted the lives of more than 600 million people since its establishment in 2003. Launched at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology by Nobel Prize in Economics winners Esther Duflo and Abhijit Banerjee with foundational support from Community Jameel, J-PAL works to reduce poverty by ensuring that policy is informed by scientific evidence through research, policy outreach and training. J-PAL's poverty alleviation approach pioneered by Esther and Abhijit uses randomised control trials to isolate evidence in order to identify the real impact of policies. J-PAL will mark its 20th anniversary in June 2023.

‍
fieldData.name: Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab helps 600m defeat poverty in 20 years
fieldData.arabic-title: معمل عبد اللطيف جميل لمكافحة الفقر يساعد 600 مليون شخص على هزيمة الفقر في 20 عامًا

fieldData.summary: As the world struggles to meet internationally agreed targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions, methods of removing carbon dioxide such as reforestation of cleared areas have become an increasingly important strategy. 2022 Abdul Latif Jameel Water and Food Systems Lab (J-WAFS) principal investigator and Seed Grant recipient, César Terrer, and recent visiting student Stephen Bell describe how agricultural lands that are no longer productive could play an important role in carbon sequestration.
fieldData.arabic-title: 3 أسئلة: هل يمكن للأراضي الزراعية المهجورة المساعدة في التخفيف من تغير المناخ؟
fieldData.name: 3 questions: Can disused croplands help mitigate climate change?
fieldData.thumbnail-alt-text: A typical post-agricultural landscape (PAL) trajectory involves land clearing from the primary forest for agricultural use and ecological succession following agricultural cessation.

fieldData.summary: Les économistes, leurs concepts, leurs outils et leurs prescriptions semblent dépassés par la nature et l’ampleur de la crise climatique en cours. Encore trop centrée sur l’homme, la science économique peut-elle se refonder pour prendre en compte l’ensemble du vivant ?
fieldData.name: Face à la crise climatique, la science économique sommée de se réinventer
fieldData.arabic-title: في مواجهة أزمة المناخ ، دعا الاقتصاديون إلى إعادة اختراع نفسه

fieldData.summary: Speaking at the second international forum combating poverty organised by the Center for Economic Research and Reforms together with the Uzbekistan Ministry of Employment and Poverty Reduction, Abhijit Banerjee, co-founder and co-director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL), highlighted that very little is known about which social programmes work and which do not, and that such programmes are implemented by governments intuitively, rather than on the basis of evidence. He commended Uzbekistan for leading by example in its use of a suite of mechanisms to implement evidence-based social programmes, including by first determining the target audience, its needs, the support required and for whom.
fieldData.name: Abhijit Banerjee: Uzbekistan shows other countries how to deal with poverty by example
fieldData.arabic-title: أبهيجيت بانيرجي: توضح أوزبكستان لدول أخرى كيفية التعامل مع الفقر بالقدوة

fieldData.summary: The Abdul Latif Jameel Water and Food Systems Lab (J-WAFS) announced its ninth round of seed grants to support research efforts that tackle food and water-related challenges, with the ultimate goal of creating meaningful impact. Ten new projects tackling a diverse set of challenges will be supported, including that of David Des Marais, 2018 J-WAFS principal investigator and the Cecil and Ida Green Career Development Professor of civil and environmental engineering at MIT, whose 2023 J-WAFS project seeks to understand plant growth responses to elevated carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, in the hopes of identifying breeding strategies that maximise crop yield. David is also ateam member of one of the 2022 MIT Climate Grand Challenges finalists for the project, 'Managing sources and sinks of carbon in terrestrial and coastal ecosystems'. Another recipient is Kripa Varanasi and Rohit Karnik, a J-WAFS principal investigator on multiple J-WAFS funded projects since 2015 and Tata Professor.
fieldData.name: J-WAFS announces 2023 seed grant recipients
fieldData.arabic-title: تعلن J-WAFS عن مستلمي المنح الأولية لعام 2023
fieldData.thumbnail-alt-text: Recipients of the 2023 J-WAFS Seed Grant for innovative research at MIT.

fieldData.summary: The Jameel Arts & Health Lab—a partnership between Community Jameel, the World Health Organisation (WHO), New York University Steinhardt School and CULTURUNNERS—was launched in 2023 to generate and amplify research into how the arts can improve the health and wellbeing of individuals and communities in some of the most challenging contexts around the world. This year, the lab will run four research studies that use music and the arts to support the lives of women with postnatal depression, genocide survivors, people with dementia and their caretakers, as well as hospital patients and healthcare staff, with the intention to use the outcomes to shape public policy across all 194 United Nations member states.
fieldData.name: Jameel Arts & Health Lab launches four international research studies
fieldData.arabic-title: مختبر جميل للفنون والصحة يطلق أربع دراسات بحثية دولية

fieldData.summary: Mental health in Africa remains under-researched and underfunded, leading to significant economic losses. However, the continent's widespread access to mobile phones presents an opportunity for innovative solutions. A study in Ghana by Belinda Archibong, researcher the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) King Climate Initiative, and Francis Annan, a J-PAL affiliated professor, showed that providing mobile calling credits to low-income adults led to a decrease in mental distress and severe mental disorders. This cost-effective approach is especially vital for low-income countries with limited government spending on health. Addressing mental health in Africa is critical, considering the young population facing various challenges. By enhancing connectivity, mobile technology can contribute to better mental wellbeing and policy interventions.
fieldData.name: Using information and communication technology to improve mental health in Africa
fieldData.arabic-title: استخدام تكنولوجيا المعلومات والاتصالات لتحسين الصحة النفسية في إفريقيا
