fieldData.summary: A recent data.org report identified an opportunity for 3.5 million jobs in data for social impact within developing countries alone over the next decade. The India Data Capacity Accelerator is a new initiative launched by data.org with funding from Wellcome and in partnership with the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) South Asia regional office, and takes a step closer to training one million, purpose-driven data practitioners in India by 2032. The accelerator will partner with three universities - Ashoka University, Birla Institute of Technology & Science, Pilani and the Indian Institute of Technology Delhi - to train emerging data practitioners in interdisciplinary data skills required to address challenges at the intersection of climate change and health.
fieldData.name: Three universities picked to train 1 million Indian students in climate, health data work
fieldData.arabic-title: اختارت ثلاث جامعات لتدريب مليون هندي على عمل البيانات الصحية والمناخية
fieldData.thumbnail-alt-text: The 'India data capacity accelerator' training programme by data.org and J-PAL will train 1 million emerging data practitioners in partnership with three Indian universities

fieldData.arabic-title: إطلاق برنامج لتدريب مليون هندي على عمل البيانات المناخية والصحية
fieldData.summary: While there is potential for 3.5 million data professionals across the world to use data to inform policy and respond to pressing global challenges, there remains significant data skills gaps across labour markets, and particularly in low- and middle-income countries. A new programme launched by data.org in partnership with the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL)'s South Asia office will work with three Indian universities to upskill one million emerging research and policy practitioners in using data to solve climate and health challenges. The programme, 'The India Data Capacity Accelerator', is funded by a USD 2.3 million grant from Wellcome.
fieldData.name: India Data Capacity Accelerator launched to train 1 million Indians in climate and health data work
fieldData.thumbnail-alt-text: The India Data Capacity Accelerator will work with three universities in India to enhance the use of data by emerging research and policy practitioners.

fieldData.excerpt:
In February the Jameel Arts & Health Lab was established to show how the arts have the power to help tackle climate change and the global health crisis.

From Dec. 1-3, the lab presented COP28 Healing Arts Week, a platform to promote the role of the arts at the intersection of health and climate. Included was a high-level panel in the COP28 Green Zone titled “Arts, Health and Climate” moderated by Princess Mashael Saud Al-Shalan, co-founder of Aeon Collective.

A panel on “Safeguarding Our Planet: Biodiversity, Climate and One Health” was held at the Saudi Pavilion in the Blue Zone featuring Princess Mashael; Prince Sultan bin Fahad, chairman of the Saudi Water Sports and Diving Federation; Princess Hala bint Khaled, president of the Khaled bin Sultan Living Oceans Foundation; Raquel Peixoto, associate professor of microbiology at King Abdullah University of Science and Technology; Richard Bush, chief environment officer at NEOM; Christopher Bailey, founding Co-Director of Jameel Arts & Health Lab; and Catherine Cone environment and sustainability director at the Royal Commission for AlUla.
fieldData.summary:
The Jameel Arts & Health Lab, a collaboration between Community Jameel, the World Health Organisation (WHO), NYU Steinhardt and CULTURUNNERS, presents COP28 Healing Arts Week from 1-3 December in Dubai, to promote the role of the arts on human and environmental health. The platform includes the 'Arts, climate & health' high-level panel in the Green Zone.

Cléa Daridan, senior curator at Community Jameel, says: “We are interested in connecting the arts and health with climate change because obviously the climate crisis is a health crisis. There’s no doubt that now the question is to understand whether or not the arts might be able to offer answers to these crises. At COP28 we were trying to explore the intersection between arts, health and climate change from a research and a policy perspective because it is through the implementation of policy that change can happen.”

Stephen Stapleton, co-director of the lab says: “The Jameel Arts & Health Lab has been at COP advocating for the important role of the arts in telling the story of the climate crisis as a health crisis. In so doing to inspire the behavioral change, on both a personal and societal level, which is so urgently needed … through arts therapies and self-expression, the arts can also help those most vulnerable to cope with the psychological impact of the perceived and real changes which are already affecting millions of people around the world.”
fieldData.name: Jameel Arts & Health Lab presents link between art, health and climate crisis at COP28
fieldData.arabic-title: (COP28) يقدم مختبر جميل للفنون والصحة الرابط بين الفن والصحة وأزمة المناخ في مؤتمر الأمم المتحدة المعني بتغير المناخ
fieldData.thumbnail-alt-text: Mikey Muhanna, Nadia Christidi, Stephen Stapleton, Uns Kattan and Clea Daridan

fieldData.summary: There have been huge investments in ‘early warning’ facilities across East Africa, prompted by previous emergencies where livestock have perished and people’s lives have been threatened. Yet, despite all the talk of early warning, disaster risk reduction, shock-responsive systems, contingency planning and anticipatory action, the end results are mixed to say the least, writes Jameel Observatory PhD student, Tahira Shariff in her latest blog article on Pastres.
fieldData.name: Local early warning systems: Predicting the future when things are so uncertain
fieldData.arabic-title: أنظمة الإنذار المبكر المحلية: توقع المستقبل عندما تكون الأمور غير مؤكدة

fieldData.summary: Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee asked health secretary Naraya to consider creating a diploma course for doctors who would be able to work primary healthcare centres in order to help mitigate the shortage of doctors in rural Bengal. In 2016, Abhijit Banerjee, co-founder and co-director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL), co-authored a study in Bengal's Birbhum, which showed that the mainstreaming of informal medical practitioners can improve unlicensed healthcare in addition to addressing doctor shortages.
fieldData.name: CM Mamata Banerjee proposes 'diploma doctors' for primary health centres
fieldData.arabic-title: سي إم ماماتا بانيرجي يقترح "أطباء دبلوم" لمراكز الصحة الأولية

fieldData.summary: On 18 May 2023, Tashkent, Uzbekistan will host the second international forum 'Application of best practices to reduce poverty'. Experts, including Abhijit Banerjee, co-founder and co-director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, will review the best practices for fighting poverty and the effectiveness of Uzbekistan’s achievements in terms of reducing domestic poverty through its state policy, with a view to further disseminating learnings with developing countries.
fieldData.name: Second international forum on combating poverty to be held in Tashkent
fieldData.arabic-title: انعقاد المنتدى الدولي الثاني حول الحد من الفقر في طشقند

fieldData.summary: The second international forum, organised by the Center for Economic Research and Reforms (CERR) together with the Uzbekistan Ministry of Employment and Poverty Reduction, will study the best practices and methods of global poverty alleviation, in addition to the effectiveness of Uzbekistan's own efforts to reduce domestic poverty which have been consistently implemented in state policy. The forum will be attended by Abhijit Banerjee, co-founder and co-director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL), which is expected to sign a joint action programme with CERR during the event.
fieldData.name: 2nd international forum on poverty reduction to be held in Tashkent
fieldData.arabic-title: انعقاد المنتدى الدولي الثاني حول الحد من الفقر في طشقند

fieldData.summary: Jameel Clinic Principal Investigator Dina Katabi and 2022 Abdul Latif Jameel Water and Food Systems Lab (J-WAFS) Principal Investigator Gang Chen are among five MIT researchers recognised by the National Academy of Sciences for their 'continuous and outstanding contributions to original research'. Membership to the Academy is one of the highest honours a scientist can receive in their career. Dina is known for her work in wireless data transmission, developing wireless devices that assist with digital health using AI and radio signals. Gang is a pioneer in nanoscale heat transfer and energy conversion, and has significantly contributed to the understanding of heat transfer and energy conversion mechanisms, developed high-performance thermoelectric materials, superior semiconductors, highly heat-conductive polymers and water desalination materials.
fieldData.name: Five MIT faculty elected to the National Academy of Sciences for 2023
fieldData.arabic-title: تم انتخاب خمسة من أعضاء هيئة التدريس بمعهد ماساتشوستس للتكنولوجيا في الأكاديمية الوطنية للعلوم لعام 2023

fieldData.summary: As successive economic shocks continue to threaten Egypt's poor, a new seminar series, ‘Bridging evidence and policy' (BEP), asks how can policymakers scale up efforts to keep the most vulnerable afloat. Launched jointly by the Egyptian Food Bank (EFB)’s Growth Lab, the International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI) and the Sawiris Foundation for Social Development (SFSD), under the auspices of Egypt’s Ministry of Social Solidarity, the series will examine the importance of evidence-based policymaking for social protection. The ethos of the event echoes that of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab in the Middle East and North Africa (J-PAL MENA), which has conducted 34 impact evaluations of social policy in Egypt spanning social protection, labor, health, education and gender, and whose methodology also informed IFPRI's impact evaluation of the Egyptian Food Bank’s general feeding programme, one of the largest RCTs implemented in Egypt.
fieldData.name: Bridging evidence and policy: New seminar series highlights role of science in strengthening Egypt’s social protection programmes
fieldData.arabic-title: تجسير الأدلة والسياسات: سلسلة ندوات جديدة تسلط الضوء على دور العلم في تعزيز برامج الحماية الاجتماعية في مصر

fieldData.summary: Date labels found on perishable foods are often poor predictors of when food will become dangerous to eat, which can lead to both food waste and food poisoning, according to Benedetto Marelli, a 2018 and 2021 principal investigator at the Abdul Latif Jameel Water and Food Systems Lab (J-WAFS) at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Benedetto and his colleagues have created a biodegradable plastic-like wrap made from silk which changes colour when exposed to rotting foods. Benedetto received a 2018 J-WAFS Seed Grant for his project 'Printed silk-based colorimetric sensors for food spoilage prevention and supply chain authentication', which developed a Velcro-like food sensor, made from an array of silk microneedles, that pierces through plastic packaging to sample food for signs of spoilage and bacterial contamination.
fieldData.name: Colour-changing wrap could let you know when food has spoiled
fieldData.arabic-title: يمكن أن يخبرك الغلاف المتغير اللون عندما يفسد الطعام
fieldData.thumbnail-alt-text: Benedetto Marelli, a J-WAFS researcher at MIT has developed a colour-changing biodegradable wrapper to detect spoiling food

fieldData.summary: The Jameel Observatory Climate Resilience Early Warning System Network (Jameel Observatory-CREWSnet) launched by Community Jameel and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) will partner with BRAC, an international development organisation, to pilot innovative climate-adaptive technologies in the south-west region of Bangladesh and Sudan. The Jameel Observatory-CREWSnet platform will empower agricultural communities in climate vulnerable countries to prepare for and respond to the impacts of climate change. Selected as an innovation sprint at the 2023 summit of the Agriculture Innovation Missions for Climate (AIM4C), a joint initiative of the United States and the United Arab Emirates, the project is led by Elfatih Eltahir, co-director of the Jameel Observatory, a research platform that uses data and evidence to prepare and act against climate shocks.
fieldData.name: BRAC, Jameel Observatory work on poverty eradication
fieldData.arabic-title: BRAC ومرصد جميل يعملان على القضاء على الفقر
تعطيل تغير المناخ: 13 مبتكرًا تقنيًا يساعدون في إنقاذ الكوكب
fieldData.summary: Few countries are on track to meet their targets to address climate change, according to a new UN report. Where governments around the world are falling behind, however, individual innovators are trying to fill the breach. These innovators include Jongyoon Han and Junghyo Yoon, researchers associated with the Abdul Latif Jameel Water and Food Systems Lab (J-WAFS) at MIT who developed a new portable desalination method that is easy to maintain and requires no additional chemicals, filters or skilled operators—delivering safe drinking water at the push of a button. Jongyoon and Junghyo's invention and spin-out company, NONA Technologies, developed from research funded by the J-WAFS Solutions Grant, which they received in 2021.
fieldData.name: Disrupting climate change: 13 tech innovators helping to save the planet

fieldData.arabic-title: يهدف تحدي J-WAFS الكبير الافتتاحي إلى تطوير أنواع محاصيل محسنة ونقلها من المختبر إلى الأرض
fieldData.summary: The inaugural Grand Challenge Grant from the Abdul Latif Jameel Water and Food Systems Lab (J-WAFS) has been awarded to a team of researchers led by Matt Shoulders, professor in MIT's department of chemistry, and includes Mary Gehring, a 2021 J-WAFS principal investigator, Bryan Bryson, associate professor of biological engineering, and Bin Zhang, associate professor of chemistry. Their project, 'Enhanced photosynthesis in crops' (EPiC), seeks to improve the RuBisCO enzyme that plants use to convert carbon dioxide into molecules that constitute food. The team will receive USD 1.5 million over three years to facilitate a multistage research project, which, if successful, could create major benefits for agriculture and food systems worldwide. 'This difficult problem is a true grand challenge. With J-WAFS’ support, this long-sought goal may finally be achieved through MIT’s leading-edge research', said J-WAFS director, John H Lienhard V.
fieldData.name: Inaugural J-WAFS Grand Challenge aims to develop enhanced crop variants and move them from lab to land

fieldData.summary: A new project launched by Community Jameel and the Jameel Observatory Climate Resilience Early Warning System Network (Jameel Observatory-CREWSnet) will partner with Bangladesh-based development organisation BRAC to pilot climate adaptation technologies in southwestern Bangladesh. Aimed at increasing the capacity of agricultural communities worldwide to handle the shocks of climate change, the platform will pilot initially in Bangladesh and Sudan. The project is led by Elfatih Eltahir, co-director of the Jameel Observatory and King HM Bhumibol Professor of Hydrology and Climate at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT). The Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab at MIT will also partner in the project to measure the effectiveness of climate change programmes.
fieldData.name: BRAC partnering with Jameel Observatory-CREWSnet project
fieldData.arabic-title: شراكة بين براك ومشروع مرصد جميل- CREWSnet

fieldData.summary: Community Jameel and the Jameel Observatory Climate Resilience Early Warning System Network (Jameel Observatory-CREWSnet) will partner with BRAC, the international development organisation based in Bangladesh, to pilot climate forecasting and adaptation technologies in southwestern Bangladesh, with a view to expanding the project to Sudan. Led by Elfatih Eltahir, co-director of the Jameel Observatory and HM King Bhumibol Professor of Hydrology and Climate at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), the platform aims to increase the capacity of agricultural communities in climate vulnerable countries worldwide to handle the challenges of climate change.
fieldData.name: BRAC, Jameel Observatory-CREWSnet project to reduce poverty with climate adaptive innovations
fieldData.arabic-title: BRAC ، مشروع مرصد جميل- CREWSnet للحد من الفقر من خلال ابتكارات التكيف مع المناخ

fieldData.summary: The rise of smart machines and artificial intelligence (AI) opens up some scary possibilities; for the economy, for democracy and even for our continued existence as a species. However, according to David Autor, a leading labour economist and affiliate professor of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) at MIT, where he is the Ford Professor of Economics, if we get our act together, the age of AI could be one in which we rebuild the middle class.
fieldData.name: What if AI could rebuild the middle class?
fieldData.arabic-title: ماذا لو تمكن الذكاء الاصطناعي من إعادة بناء الطبقة الوسطى؟

fieldData.summary: The Jameel Observatory Climate Resilience Early Warning System Network (Jameel Observatory-CREWSnet), a new project launched by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) and Community Jameel, has been selected as an innovation sprint at the 2023 summit of the Agriculture Innovation Mission for Climate (AIM4C). AIM4C is a joint initiative of the United States and United Arab Emirates that seeks to enhance climate action by accelerating agriculture and food systems innovation and investment. Piloted initially in Bangladesh in partnership with BRAC, the Jameel Observatory-CREWSnet platform combines climate and socioeconomic forecasting techniques with technological solutions to empower communities worldwide to adapt to climate shocks.
fieldData.name: Jameel Observatory early warning system showcased by US and UAE governments at climate change summit in Washington, DC
fieldData.arabic-title: نظام إنذار مبكر لمرصد جميل عرضته حكومتا الولايات المتحدة والإمارات في قمة تغير المناخ في واشنطن العاصمة

fieldData.excerpt:
The Jameel Observatory Climate Resilience Early Warning System Network (CREWSnet), a new project of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) and Community Jameel, a global organisation to advance science and learning for communities to thrive, will partner with BRAC to pilot innovative climate-adaptive technologies in the southwest region of Bangladesh.

The Jameel Observatory-CREWSnet project was selected in an innovation sprint at the 2023 summit of the Agriculture Innovation Mission for Climate (AIM4C), a joint initiatives of the United States and the United Arab Emirates.

The Jameel Observatory-CREWSnet will initially pilot in Bangladesh and Sudan, working with local partners BRAC and the Agricultural Research Corporation (ARC) - Sudan, main agricultural research arm of the Sudanese government, and with MIT’s Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL), the global research centre working to reduce poverty by ensuring that policy is informed by scientific evidence.
fieldData.summary:
The Jameel Observatory Climate Resilience Early Warning System Network (CREWSnet), supported by Community Jameel and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), launch a partnership with BRAC to pilot innovative climate-adaptive technologies using climate forecasting and predictive analytics in southwest Bangladesh.

‍George Richards, director of Community Jameel, said, “Community Jameel is proud to be collaborating with MIT, BRAC, and the Agricultural Research Corporation - Sudan to empower agricultural communities to adapt to the ever-growing challenges arising from climate change – challenges which, as we are seeing acutely in Sudan, are compounded by other crises. We welcome the support of the US and UAE governments in selecting the Jameel Observatory-CREWSnet as an AIM4C innovation sprint.”
fieldData.name: BRAC and Jameel Observatory-CREWSnet project begin partnership
fieldData.arabic-title: BRAC ومشروع مرصد جميل-CREWSnet يبدأان الشراكة

fieldData.summary: MIT and Community Jameel have launched the Jameel Observatory Climate Resilience Early Warning System Network (Jameel Observatory-CREWSnet) to build community resilience to climate change effects. The project, recognised as an innovation sprint at the 2023 AIM4C summit, aims to empower agriculture communities to adapt to climate shocks through cross-sector collaborations and technological solutions. It will initially pilot in Bangladesh and Sudan, leveraging climate forecasting, predictive analytics, and new technologies to support sustainable agriculture and enhance resilience. The initiative emphasises integrating local climate insights to proactively manage climate risks and economic opportunities.
fieldData.name: US and UAE governments highlight early warning system for climate resilience
fieldData.arabic-title: تسلط حكومتا الولايات المتحدة والإمارات العربية المتحدة الضوء على نظام الإنذار المبكر من أجل التكيف مع تغير المناخ
fieldData.thumbnail-alt-text: A man inspects sunflower seeds in a sunflower field in Bangladesh.

fieldData.summary: The Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) Europe office named Uzbekistan its 'country of the month' for May, in recognition of the nation's progress in developing comprehensive policies to overcome poverty and improve social protection in recent years. In May 2022, J-PAL, which was co-founded by Nobel Prize for Economics winners Abhijit Banerjee and Esther Duflo, together with the Centre for Economic Research and Reforms, organised a seminar in cooperation with the Uzbekistan government to assist in the development and testing of innovative approaches to improve state programmes designed to combat poverty.
fieldData.name: J-PAL Europe names Uzbekistan country of the month
fieldData.arabic-title: تحدد J-PAL Europe أوزبكستان دولة الشهر

fieldData.summary: Innovations for Poverty Action (IPA) and the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) have announced a five-year, USD 10 million grant from the IKEA Foundation in support of research on the effectiveness of livelihood programmes for refugee and displaced populations and their host communities. Part of J-PAL's Displaced Livelihoods Initiative, the fund is the first of its kind and will help IPA and J-PAL generate data to inform policy makers and practitioners as they design evidence-based policies and programmes that aim to support displaced people to create sustainable livelihoods and achieve self-reliance.
fieldData.name: IKEA Foundation commits USD 10 million to IPA and J-PAL to study refugee work programmes
fieldData.arabic-title: تلتزم مؤسسة ايكيا بمبلغ 10 ملايين دولار لدراسة برامج عمل اللاجئين

fieldData.summary: Despite concerns that doctors will become a relic of the past, AI is not a threat but an component in the future of health care. One key source of optimism is the work of AI Faculty Lead at the MIT Jameel Clinic, Regina Barzilay, who built an AI algorithm called Mirai, which improves the analysis of mammograms and detection of potentially cancerous cells among women. Mirai is currently undergoing trials at eight locations around the world, testing around 200,000 women.
fieldData.name: Why AI is set to become an important healthcare tool, not a threat
fieldData.arabic-title: لماذا تم تعيين الذكاء الاصطناعي ليصبح أداة رعاية صحية مهمة ، وليس تهديدًا

fieldData.summary: The coronation concert held on Sunday, 7 May 2023, brings together global music icons, contemporary stars and alumni and affiliates of the Royal College of Music (RCM) in celebration of crowning of King Charles III. The line-up included bass-baritone Sir Bryn Terfel and tenor Andrea Bocelli, whose foundation supports the RCM through the Andrea Bocelli Foundation-Community Jameel scholarship. Launched in 2019, the scholarship supports a talented musician to study at RCM's renowned opera studio each year.
fieldData.name: Royal College of Music musicians take part in Westminster Abbey service and Windsor Castle coronation concert
fieldData.arabic-title: يحتل موسيقيو الكلية الملكية للموسيقى مكانهم في التاريخ كجزء من خدمة كنيسة وستمنستر وحفل تتويج قلعة وندسور

fieldData.summary: For the Mittal Institute's Harish C Mahindra lecture this year, Indian-American actress Madhur Jaffrey shared stories from her upbringing in British India, her acting career and how she became an icon of South Asian cooking globally. Jaffrey was then interviewed by Abhijit Banerjee, co-founder and co-director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) and publisher of his own cookbook, 'Cooking to save your life', who asked her what she believes should be India's national dish. 'We’re too diverse a nation to have any one dish', she quipped.
fieldData.name: Abhijit Banerjee talks to Madhur Jaffrey about the subtleties of South Asian cooking
fieldData.arabic-title: مادهور جافري عن التفاصيل الدقيقة للطبخ في جنوب آسيا

fieldData.summary: Established by an Act of Congress and signed by President Abraham Lincoln in 1863, the National Academy of Sciences (NAS) recognises outstanding and original contributions to research. Today, the NAS announced the election of 120 members and 23 international members including Dina Katabi, principal investigator at the MIT Jameel Clinic, the epicentre of artificial intelligence (AI) and healthcare at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT). Dina was recognised for her outstanding research on wireless systems and AI, which have had a significant impact on the field.
fieldData.name: National Academy of Sciences elects Jameel Clinic PI Dina Katabi
fieldData.arabic-title: الأكاديمية الوطنية للعلوم تنتخب الباحثة الرئيسية في عيادة جميل دينا قتابي

fieldData.excerpt:
Community Jameel Saudi Arabia, a member of the Jameel Global Learning Lab network at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, announced the launch of the seventh edition of the “StartSmart” entrepreneurship competition in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, which is co-organized by Bab Rizq Jameel. This annual competition is one of the oldest entrepreneurship competitions in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia and the most distinguished at the regional level. It aims to strengthen the Saudi entrepreneurship system, empower entrepreneurs and encourage them to innovate, increase the number of small and medium enterprises, and contribute to providing new jobs in the local market.

Registration for the competition opens on April 27 and continues until June 16 on the competition’s website. Participation will be available to Saudi entrepreneurs of all ages and economic sectors within one of the competition’s four tracks: the ideas track, the startups track, the social companies track, and the newly launched environment track. For the first time.  The organizers will hold a series of introductory tours in Saudi cities to familiarize entrepreneurs with the criteria and mechanisms for applying for the competition and to help them complete their applications.

Teams participating in the four tracks of the competition will receive many advantages and benefits, such as receiving high-level training from the most prominent entrepreneurship experts in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, as well as participating in special sessions for guidance, counselling, and individual education, the possibility of appearing on the media, and providing networking and building opportunities. Relationships and communication between entrepreneurs, investors, business incubators, senior leaders and executives from the private and government sectors, within a five-month journey full of excitement and challenges. The twelve winning teams in the four competition tracks will be awarded lucrative financial prizes, in addition to a group of other benefits that will be announced later.
fieldData.summary:
Community Jameel Saudi Arabia and Bab Rizq Jameel launch the seventh annual edition of StartSmart, an entrepreneurial competition held in Saudi Arabia with the aim of empowering entrepreneurs to innovate, expand and create local jobs.

May Taibah, CEO of Bab Rizq Jameel, says of the event: "We at the Saudi Community Jameel Foundation and Bab Rizq Jameel are honored to organise this huge annual competition, which has proven over the years its great impact in providing knowledge, communication, training and financing for Saudi entrepreneurs, enabling them to transform their ideas into startup companies and accelerate their growth to change the face of the world.”

Mohammed Abdul Ghaffar, general manager of entrepreneurship and social initiatives at Community Jameel Saudi Arabia, adds: “Our organisation seeks to contribute to achieving social, economic and environmental prosperity in line with the Kingdom’s Vision 2030, and it motivates us to work hard to launch initiatives that develop the skills of Saudi youth and empower them economically. The competition comes Start Smart is a motivating factor for Saudi youth to enter the field of entrepreneurship from its widest range, and encourages them to excel and compete in a platform that provides them with support and guidance to reach new heights of success and growth."

Esther Duflo, co-director and co-founder of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) at MIT, suggests that the fight against climate change should learn from the fight against global poverty. Instead of relying on "miracle solutions," she advocates for multiple concrete measures that have proven effective. Over the past 30 years, significant progress has been made in reducing extreme poverty worldwide, with the poverty rate decreasing from 15% to 8%. This achievement resulted not only from China and India's economic growth but also from a shift in focus towards various development areas like education, health, women's rights, and the environment.

Esther Duflo, alongside MIchael Kremer and her husband Abhijit Banerjee, who is also co-director and co-founder of J-PAL, won the 2019 Nobel Prize in Economics for their pragmatic and evidence-based approach. Duflo and her team have improved policies and programs for over 600 million people, primarily in developing countries. By testing and implementing approaches like providing free mosquito nets to combat malaria and simplifying the water connection process for the poor in Morocco, they have achieved significant positive outcomes.

Duflo aims to challenge the misconception that financial assistance makes people lazy, emphasising that evidence repeatedly disproves this notion. However, progress in poverty reduction is threatened by climate change, disproportionately impacting developing nations. Duflo urges moving away from a search for a single miraculous solution to climate change, advocating instead for multiple coordinated actions over time to yield tangible progress, much like the approach taken in poverty reduction.
fieldData.name: Les «plombiers» de la science au secours du climat
fieldData.thumbnail-alt-text: Jacques Nadeau Le Devoir Esther Duflo aime comparer son travail à celui «d’un plombier» qui cherche surtout à comprendre la situation sans a priori, qui prête attention aux détails et qui a recours à une bonne dose d’essais et d’erreurs.
fieldData.arabic-title: المثابرة والتزام العلماء في مكافحة التغير المناخي

fieldData.summary: Nineteen scientists from seven nations assessed how climate change affected rainfall in the region and Eastern Africa made worse by human, induced climate change, which will be much likelier to occur in the first place. Guyo Malicha Roba, head of the Jameel Observatory, said the food situation in the horn of Africa's drylands has been historically addressed by raising money and with food distributions from governments and humanitarian partners, but more work needs to be done to use early-warning systems to respond more quickly to 'food shocks'.
fieldData.name: How climate change worsened Eastern Africa's drought
fieldData.arabic-title: كيف أدى تغير المناخ إلى تفاقم الجفاف في شرق إفريقيا
fieldData.thumbnail-alt-text: The United Nations said more than 20 million people in Kenya, Ethiopia, Somalia, Uganda, and South Sudan had been affected by the drought, with more than 2.2 million displaced in Somalia and Ethiopia and severe maternal risks to hundreds of thousands of expectant or breastfeeding women.

fieldData.summary: Scientists say that rising greenhouse gas emissions made the drought in the Horn of Africa at least 100 times more likely. A group of 19 international scientists, including Guyo Roba, head of the Jameel Observatory, assessed how climate change affected rainfall in the region in a report published by the World Weather Attribution.
fieldData.name: Global warming made Horn of Africa drought possible: WWA study

fieldData.summary:
The ongoing drought in eastern Africa has been made worse by human-induced climate change, which also made it much likelier to occur in the first place, an international team of climate scientists, including Guyo Malicha Roba, head of the Jameel Observatory, has concluded. The report was published by the World Weather Attribution, a group that seeks to quickly determine whether certain extreme weather events were influenced by climate change.

‍

fieldData.summary:
An international team of climate scientists, including Guyo Roba, head of the Jameel Observatory, announced that the ongoing drought in eastern Africa has been made worse by human-induced climate change, in a report from World Weather Attribution. The United Nations said more than 20 million people in Kenya, Ethiopia, Somalia, Uganda and South Sudan have been affected by the drought, with more than 2.2 million displaced in Somalia and Ethiopia.

‍

According to Guyo Malicha Roba, head of the Jameel Observatory, the food situation in the region’s drylands has been addressed by raising money and with food distributions from governments and humanitarian partners, but more work needs to be done to use early warning systems to respond more quickly to food shocks.
