fieldData.summary: Providing access to childcare can help women achieve greater economic parity and enhance their agency, and could also lead to a substantial boost to the global economy. Selim Gulesci, associate professor of economics at Trinity College Dublin and affiliate of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) joins VoxDevTalks to discuss recent research on how childcare can empower women in developing countries. Selim's research is centred on development economics, labor and gender.
fieldData.name: How childcare empowers women
fieldData.arabic-title: كيف تمكّن رعاية الأطفال النساء

fieldData.summary: Today, over 100 million people have been forcibly displaced to escape violence, conflict, or persecution. Projected to continue growing, displacement is also intertwined with poverty, food insecurity and climate change. The newly-launched Displaced Livelihoods Initiative (DLI), which will be jointly managed by Innovations for Poverty Action (IPA) and the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL), with generous support from the IKEA Foundation, is the world’s first research fund dedicated to generating rigorous experimental and quasi-experimental evidence to inform policies and programmes that can foster sustainable livelihoods for displaced and host communities.
fieldData.name: New Displaced Livelihoods Initiative will help advance sustainable livelihoods for displaced and host communities
fieldData.arabic-title: ستساعد مبادرة سبل عيش النازحين الجديدة على تعزيز سبل العيش المستدامة للنازحين والمجتمعات المضيفة

fieldData.summary: Esther Duflo, co-founder and co-director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) and winner of the Nobel Prize in Economics (2019), gave her inaugural lecture at the Collège de France last autumn, where she is now professor. The lecture, which focused on the fight against poverty and development economics in an increasingly uncertain future, has now been published.
fieldData.name: Charles Jaigu: « Le rattrapage des pays pauvres à l’arrêt »
fieldData.arabic-title: تشارلز جايجو: "اللحاق بالبلدان الفقيرة في طريق مسدود"

fieldData.summary: The economic advisory council of the Tamil Nadu government, which boasts the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) co-founder and co-director, Esther Duflo, former Reserve Bank of India (RBI) governor Raghuram Rajan and development economist Jean Drèze, among others, was established to advise Chief Minister Stalin on economic matters concerning the Indian state of Tamil Nandu. On 24 April, Stalin halted further action on the Factories (Tamil Nandu Amendment) Act 2023, which aimed at flexible work hours in factories. Drèze hoped that the Tamil Nandu government will defend the amendment, warning that in its current form, it would jeopardise women's labour rights in particular.
fieldData.name: Tamil Nadu government did not consult economic advisory council before it amended Factories Act: Jean Drèze
fieldData.arabic-title: لم تستشر حكومة تاميل نادو المجلس الاستشاري الاقتصادي قبل أن تعدل قانون المصانع: جان دريز

fieldData.summary:
Starting about five years ago, the Indonesian government stopped sending 10-kilogram bags of rice to villages and began sending debit cards instead so people could buy the food themselves. The result, according to a study led in part by Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) researchers, including J-PAL's co-founder and co-director, Abhijit Banerjee, was that people received all the food intended for them 81% of the time—as opposed to 24% previously. Under the old system, it’s likely that some was handed out to people not poor enough to be eligible. The cards eliminated this problem.

‍
fieldData.name: Going digital makes aid programmes more effective
fieldData.arabic-title: التحول الرقمي يجعل برامج المساعدة أكثر فعالية

fieldData.summary: Eight Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) faculty members are among more than 250 leaders from academia, the arts, industry, public policy and research elected to the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, one of the most prestigious honorary societies and a leading centre for independent policy research. Among those elected is Evelyn Wang, principal investigator (2017, 2021) at the Abdul Latif Jameel Water and Food Systems Lab (J-WAFS) and head of MIT's department of mechanical engineering. In 2022, Evelyn was appointed the director of the US department of energy’s 'Advanced research projects agency-energy' to support critical energy research.
fieldData.name: Eight MIT faculty elected to American Academy of Arts and Sciences for 2023
fieldData.arabic-title: انتخب ثمانية من معهد ماساتشوستس للتكنولوجيا في الأكاديمية الأمريكية للفنون والعلوم لعام 2023

fieldData.summary: Tahmina was a junior studying computer engineering at a top university in Afghanistan when a new government policy banned women from pursuing education. Determined to continue her studies and pursue her ambitions, Tahmina found the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Refugee Action Hub (MIT ReACT) and was accepted onto its certificate in computer science and data science programme in 2022. MIT ReACT provides education and professional opportunities to learners from refugee and forcibly displaced communities worldwide.
fieldData.name: Learner in Afghanistan reaches beyond barriers to pursue career in data science
fieldData.arabic-title: يتجاوز المتعلم في أفغانستان الحواجز لمتابعة حياته المهنية في علم البيانات

fieldData.summary: In a new partnership, the artists and researchers known as Cooking Sections have launched a three-year programme in collaboration with the Royal College of Architecture (RCA) in London and Community Jameel. The collaboration, entitled CLIMAVORE x Jameel at RCA, will allow Daniel Pascual Fernández and Alon Schwabe of Cooking Sections to focus on two large-scale projects analysing how climate change is affecting the food we eat and the way we grow it. One of two projects will study the water buffaloes in Turkish wetlands endangered by a major development project.
fieldData.name: Art and research duo Cooking Sections expands project to save Turkey's water buffaloes
fieldData.arabic-title: توسع أقسام الطبخ الخاصة بالفن والبحث العلمي مشروعها لإنقاذ جواميس الماء في تركيا

fieldData.summary: The decision in early 2021 to delay people’s second COVID-19 jabs caused huge controversy in the United Kingdom, but research has now found that this saved thousands of lives, according to a retrospective analysis from researchers at the Jameel Institute at Imperial College London. The study, authored by director of the Jameel Institute, Neil Ferguson, and epidemiologist, Anne Cori, among others, aimed to quantify the impact of delaying the delivery of second vaccine doses on the epidemic in England and found that the delay may have prevented 58,000 hospital admissions and 10,000 deaths between 8 December 2020 and 13 September 2021.
fieldData.name: Delaying second COVID-19 jab ‘saved thousands of lives’
fieldData.arabic-title: تأجيل ضربة جديدة لكوفيد -19 "أنقذ آلاف الأرواح"

fieldData.summary:
A team of researchers at the Abdul Latif Jameel Clinic, the epicentre of AI and healthcare at MIT, have developed is a new AI tool called Sybil that can detect lung cancer risk up to years in advance. Much like the Greek oracles its named after, Sybil's job is to see into the future and has the potential to detect lung cancer—the leading cause of cancer death in the United States—years before doctors or radiologists can. According to Regina Barzilay, AI faculty lead at MIT Jameel Clinic and a researcher on the Sybil project, 'AI in health care is one of the most under-utilised areas of applications of AI'.

‍
fieldData.name: Could AI be the key to detecting lung cancer years in advance?
fieldData.arabic-title: هل يمكن أن يكون الذكاء الاصطناعي هو المفتاح للكشف عن سرطان الرئة قبل سنوات؟

fieldData.summary: Ahead of the announcement of the 2023 winner of the Nobel Prize in Economics, the 2019 winner of the prize, and co-founder of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab, Esther Duflo, comments on the recently promulgated pension reforms in France. In an article in La Tribune, Esther considers the pension reform 'regressive' and overly complicated, bearing adverse impact on the country's poorest pensioners. She also dissects the impact of hyperinflation on the poor and pleads for the creation of a special fund for low-income countries financed by an increase in the minimum global tax on companies currently set at 15%.
fieldData.name: Esther Duflo: « Je ne vois rien de rationnel dans ce projet de réforme des retraites »
fieldData.arabic-title: "لا أرى شيئًا منطقيًا في مشروع إصلاح المعاشات التقاعدية هذا" (إستر دوفلو)

fieldData.summary: Despite long weeks of protest in response to pension reforms in France, the head of state has promulgated the proposed retirement plans during the same week as the announcement of the Nobel Prize in Economics. The 2019 Nobel Prize winner, Esther Duflo, and co-founder and co-director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL), has stated that she sees nothing 'rational' in the pension plan in an article in La Tribune, asserting that 'this reform will make it possible to save money, but at the expense of the poorest'.
fieldData.name: L’économiste Esther Duflo dézingue la réforme des retraites
fieldData.arabic-title: الخبيرة الاقتصادية إستر دوفلو تقرع إصلاح نظام التقاعد

fieldData.summary: Egypt's National Council for Women announced an upcoming study by the Egypt Impact Lab, in partnership with the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab Middle East and North Africa (J-PAL MENA), to measure the impact of 'Tahwesha', its digital savings and lending programme. The 'Tahwesha' programme aims to enhance financial inclusion for Egyptian women, particularly in rural villages, by providing them with digital financial services, integrating them into the official banking system, and raising financial awareness and digital literacy among women.
fieldData.name: Egyptian National Women's Council 'Tahwesha' programme targets 1.2 million women in all governorates within three years
fieldData.arabic-title: قومي المرأة : "تحويشة" يستهدف مليونا و200 ألف سيدة بكل المحافظات خلال 3 سنوات

fieldData.summary: Launched at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) in 2003 with foundational support from Community Jameel, the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) has impacted the lives of 600 million people through its work to reduce poverty by ensuring that policy is informed by scientific evidence through research, policy outreach and training. Its approach to poverty alleviation is spearheaded by J-PAL co-founders Abhijit Banerjee and Esther Duflo, winners of the Nobel Prize in Economics in 2019 together with their longtime associate Michael Kremer, and uses randomised control trials to isolate evidence in order to identify the real impact of poverty-prevention policies.
fieldData.name: How the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab has impacted 600 million lives in 20 years
fieldData.arabic-title: كيف أثر مختبر عبد اللطيف جميل لمكافحة الفقر على 600 مليون شخص في 20 عامًا

fieldData.summary: Gokul Sampath and Jie Yun have been named 2023 Abdul Latif Jameel Water and Food Systems Lab (J-WAFS) fellows. Awarded to outstanding PhD students at MIT working on water and food-related challenges, both students were recognised for their 'passion to solve issues of agricultural sustainability and resilience and access to safe water', said J-WAFS executive director, Renee J Robins. A former research associate at the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab, where he conducted randomised control trials in India, Gokul's research focused on strategies to address the arsenic crisis in India and Bangladesh. Jie studies plant response to drought stress in the hopes of improving agricultural sustainability and yield under climate change. She is advised by David Des Marais and has collaborated with Caroline Uhler’s group in the department of electrical engineering and computer science to use computational tools to evaluate plant resilience and adaptation.
fieldData.name: MIT PhD students honoured for their work to solve critical issues in water and food
fieldData.arabic-title: تكريم طلاب الدكتوراه في معهد ماساتشوستس للتكنولوجيا لعملهم في حل القضايا الحرجة في الماء والغذاء

fieldData.summary: A woman in China has become the first person to die from a type of bird flu that is rare in humans. Some experts warn that the world could be 'sleepwalking' into a new pandemic. Professor Neil Ferguson, director of the Jameel Institute at Imperial College London, the researcher whose modelling was instrumental to informing policy during the COVID-19 pandemic, is said to be working on a COVID-style model for a bird flu pandemic following warnings from the World Health Organisation that it poses the biggest pandemic threat to the world after COVID-19. Neil's work on improving resilience in the face of future pandemic threats coincides with the aims of the Jameel Institute-Kenneth C Griffin Initiative for the Economics of Pandemic Preparedness, launched in 2022.
fieldData.name: Could bird flu be the next COVID-19? Why experts are warning Britain of ‘sleepwalking’ into a new pandemic
fieldData.arabic-title: هل يمكن أن تكون أنفلونزا الطيور هي كوفيد القادم؟ لماذا يحذر الخبراء بريطانيا من "السير أثناء النوم" نحو جائحة جديد

fieldData.summary: Scientists from the MIT Jameel Clinic and Massachusetts General Hospital, including Jameel Clinic's AI faculty lead, Regina Barzilay, have developed a new AI tool which can detect the first symptoms of lung cancer even before they are noticeable on a CT scan. Named Sybil, in honour of the sibyls, who were prophetesses in Greek and Roman mythology, the first results of studies released last January indicated that the tool predicted whether a person could develop cancer over the course of a year with an accuracy of between 86% and 94%.
fieldData.name: Inteligencia artificial promete detectar el cáncer de pulmón antes que las tomografías, según expertos
fieldData.arabic-title: يقول الخبراء إن الذكاء الاصطناعي يعد باكتشاف سرطان الرئة قبل الأشعة المقطعية

fieldData.summary: For the past three decades, the gap between the rate of men and women's participation in the Indonesian labour force has remained stagnant (83.01% and 55.04% respectively, according to 2018 national bureau statistics). However, a more recent survey by the United Nations Development Program and the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) South-East Asia conducted across eight cities in Indonesia in 2021, finds that, on average, women work more hours doing non employment-related tasks. The survey reveals a higher proportion of women devote, on average, more than three hours per day of domestic labor compared to men, while a higher proportion of men devote, on average, more than two hours a day to domestic production.
fieldData.name: Transformer l’économie des soins en modifiant les pratiques de travail de soins non rémunérés pour favoriser l’autonomisation des femmes
fieldData.arabic-title: تحويل اقتصاد الرعاية من خلال تغيير ممارسات عمل الرعاية غير مدفوعة الأجر لتمكين المرأة

fieldData.summary: Doctors and engineers from the MIT Jameel Clinic and Massachusetts General Hospital are developing method that could revolutionise cancer detection through an artificial intelligence program called Sybil. Their study, published by researchers including Regina Barzilay, AI faculty lead at the MIT Jameel Clinic, found that Sybil could accurately predict whether a person will develop lung cancer in the next year up to 94 percent of the time.
fieldData.name: AI could revolutionise cancer detection, according to MIT, Mass General research
fieldData.arabic-title: يمكن للذكاء الاصطناعي أن يحدث ثورة في اكتشاف السرطان، وفقًا لما ذكره معهد ماساتشوستس للتكنولوجيا ، البحوث العامة الجماعية

fieldData.summary: The use of AI in drug development raises questions about the trustworthiness and transparency of the technology. That said, Jim Collins, principal investigator at the MIT Jameel Clinic, believes that AI can be a powerful tool in drug development in spite of its pitfalls. In 2020, Jim and a team of researchers discovered Halicin using AI, a new antibiotic which was effective at treating a range of bacteria, including some that are antibiotic-resistant. While the discovery of Halicin is a significant breakthrough, Collins recognises the need for greater collaboration between researchers, pharmaceutical companies and regulatory agencies to ensure that AI is used responsibly and effectively in drug development.
fieldData.name: AI for drug development: How trustworthy is the tech?
fieldData.arabic-title: الذكاء الاصطناعي لتطوير الأدوية: ما مدى جدارة التكنولوجيا بالثقة؟

fieldData.name: India's Bihar leads efforts to strengthen global poverty alleviation through South-South knowledge exchange
fieldData.arabic-title: تقود ولاية بيهار الهندية الجهود المبذولة لتعزيز التخفيف من حدة الفقر على مستوى العالم من خلال تبادل المعرفة بين بلدان الجنوب
fieldData.summary: Bihar, the largest state in terms of population in India, announced the launch of a new programme for immersion and learning exchange. The new programme will be launched under the Bihar Rural Livelihoods Promotion Society, known as JEEVIKA, which also implements Satat Jeevikoparjan Yojana (SJY), a government-led poverty alleviation programme in Bihar that has reached over 150,000 households as of 2023 and continues to expand. SJY aims to support people in extreme poverty and the most excluded households through the 'Graduation' approach, a model invented by BRAC in 2002, which is an evidence-based, multifaceted set of interventions that includes support of consumption, livelihoods, savings and training. A rigorous study of the 'Graduation' approach in West Bengal by co-founders and co-directors of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab, Abhijit Banerjee and Esther Duflo, demonstrates that 'Graduation' provides people with the resources and skills needed to break the poverty trap.

In his opening speech at a concert to mark the 75th anniversary of the World Health Organisation (WHO) in Geneva, Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus remarked on the achievements of WHO since its founding in 1948 in the aftermath of World War II, including the eradication of diseases such as smallpox and polio and the formal recognition of health as a fundamental human right for all people. He also acknowledged the many challenges faced and those that are ongoing, which the COVID-19 pandemic demonstrated so powerfully. He closed by highlighting the power of the arts for health and wellbeing, and for building vibrant communities and societies, noting also the establishment of the Jameel Arts & Health Lab in this regard, WHO's first ever arts and health laboratory. Co-led by Christopher Bailey, the lab aims to amplify scientific research into the impacts of the arts on health and wellbeing to promote the integration of the arts into mainstream healthcare.
fieldData.name: WHO director general's opening remarks at WHO 75th anniversary concert at Victoria Hall
fieldData.arabic-title: الملاحظات الافتتاحية للمدير العام لمنظمة الصحة العالمية في حفل الذكرى الخامسة والسبعين لمنظمة الصحة العالمية في قاعة فيكتوريا - 8 أبريل 2023

fieldData.summary: Le chercheur et professeur affilié au Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL), rappelle, dans une tribune au « Monde », que les études économiques s’accordent toutes sur le fait que l’immigration n’a pas de conséquence négative sur l’emploi dans le pays hôte et qu’une vraie politique d’intégration induit même des effets positifs.
fieldData.name: Luc Behaghel, économiste : « L’immigration bénéficie au pays d’accueil »
fieldData.arabic-title: لوك بيهاغل ، خبير اقتصادي: "الهجرة تفيد البلد المضيف"

fieldData.summary: The role of creative activities and projects to help people recover from trauma associated with personal or group conflict was a strong theme of the 2023 Creative Brain Week at Trinity College Dublin in March. Various speakers presented powerful examples of how being involved in creative activities can improve physical and psychological health while building valuable social connections. Speakers included Christopher Bailey, co-lead of the Jameel Arts & Health Lab, the World Health Organisation’s (WHO’s) first ever arts and health laboratory, and Nils Fietje, WHO regional office in Copenhagen, both of whom highlighted how creative projects can be undervalued in medicine and emphasised the deficit of measuring the value of artistic interventions on health. Launched in New York in February 2023, the Jameel Arts & Health lab aims to remedy this by amplifying scientific research into how the arts can improve health and wellbeing.
fieldData.name: Can creative arts projects help people deal with trauma from personal or group conflict?
fieldData.arabic-title: هل يمكن لمشاريع الفنون الإبداعية أن تساعد الأشخاص في التعامل مع الصدمات الناتجة عن الصراع الشخصي أو الجماعي؟
كتاب شوبا دي يتأرجح بين الكئيب والخطير ومبهج في وصفه لكل شيء بنغالي.
fieldData.summary: Shobhaa De's memoir 'Insatiable: My hunger for life' offers reflections on mortality, everyday fears and vanities as the writer approached her 75th birthday. Written in the the shadow the COVID-19 pandemic, Shobhaa chronicles a year of attempting to bring together family and friends in diverse places, her pursuit of writing as well as the rituals and rhythms of literary and cultural festivities, and ties them all together with food. She offers anecdotes and portrayals of friends who share in similar passions, including Abhijit Banerjee, co-founder and co-director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) and author of 'Cooking to save your life', a collection of home-cooking recipes interspersed with his economic insights.
fieldData.name: Shobhaa De's book oscillates between the sombre and serious and is delightful in its description of everything Bengali

fieldData.arabic-title: الأطباء يغرقون في الأعمال الورقية. تزعم بعض الشركات أن الذكاء الاصطناعي يمكن أن يساعد
fieldData.summary: Start-up companies claim that new machine learning programmes similar to ChatGPT could complete doctors' paperwork for them. However, some experts are concerned that inherent bias and a tendency to fabricate facts could result in errors. Among them is Marzyeh Ghassemi, principal investigator at the MIT Jameel Clinic, the epicentre of AI and healthcare at MIT, who is worried that a rush to incorporate the latest AI technology into medicine could lead to errors and biased outcomes that may harm patients. "When you take state-of-the-art machine learning methods and systems and then evaluate them on different patient groups, they do not perform equally," Marzyeh said in an interview with NPR. "That's because these systems are trained on vast amounts of data generated by humans. And whether that data is from the internet or a medical study, it contains all the human biases that already exist in our society."
fieldData.name: Doctors are drowning in paperwork. Some companies claim AI can help

fieldData.summary: Mohannad Hesham Abouelrouse, founder and CEO of the Egyptian foundation, Life From Water, spoke at the third general session of the Arab Forum for Sustainable Development organised by the United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Western Asia (ESCWA) on 23 March 2023, and asserted that civil society can play a role in achieving water security, one of the key Sustainable Development Goals. Life From Water, an Egyptian non-profit organisation with branches in Germany and Canada established, has built partnerships with Egyptian civil society organisations to improve water access in Egypt's Fayoum, Assyut, Sohag and Qena communities. In order to achieve water security, Muhannad emphasised that policy makers need to realise the importance of inclusiveness, data sharing and cooperation between parties as well as the importance of measuring the impact of water policies and projects in the Arab world.
fieldData.name: How can civil society contribute toward achieving water security?
fieldData.arabic-title: كيف يساهم المجتمع المدني في تحقيق "الأمن المائي"؟ (حوار)

fieldData.summary: Allurion, a company dedicated to ending obesity, announced it has appointed Regina Barzilay, AI faculty lead at the MIT Jameel Clinic, to its scientific advisory board, chaired by Professor Bob Langer. Allurion generates millions of data points on consumers from over 60 countries who use the company’s platform to lose weight. Regina and colleagues on the advisory board will help drive cutting-edge AI across Allurion’s business to leverage data to improve outcomes for consumers. Dr Shantanu Gaur, founder and CEO of Allurion, commented, '[Regina's] experience at the intersection of AI and healthcare to improve patient outcomes is unparalleled and will be vital as we expand the use of machine learning and natural language processing in the Allurion Virtual Care Suite and Iris AI Platform'.
fieldData.name: Allurion announces appointment of MIT Distinguished Professor for AI and Health Regina Barzilay to scientific advisory board
fieldData.arabic-title: Allurion تعلن عن تعيين أستاذ متميز في معهد ماساتشوستس للتكنولوجيا للذكاء الاصطناعي والصحة وماك آرثر منح العبقري الزميلة ريجينا بارزيلاي إلى المجلس الاستشاري العلم
من التجارة الدولية إلى أسعار الفائدة ، فإن الاقتصاد الكلي في اتجاه آخر
fieldData.name: From international trade to interest rates, macroeconomics is in yet another tail spin
fieldData.summary: In response to the Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR) calculation that a new trade deal between the UK and the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) would only add 0.08% to the size of the UK economy, despite the fact that the share of CPTPP countries' world output—not including India and China—is near to that of the European Union, Paul Ormerod argues that the UK trade perspective reveals shortcomings in contemporary understanding of macroeconomics. Whereas microeconomics has made a lot of progress over the past thirty years to understand how individuals and companies behave, the same cannot be said of macroeconomics. Ormerod points to the illustration of this provided by co-founders and co-directors of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) and Nobel Laureates, Abhijit Banerjee and Esther Duflo, in their book 'Good economics for hard times'.

A new three-year partnership between the Royal College of Art (RCA), Community Jameel and the London-based former Turner Prize nominees Cooking Sections has been announced by the institution in the hopes of using architecture as a tool to advance our knowledge of agriculture-related sustainability practices in the built environment. The initiative is being led by Cooking Sections co-founders Alon Schwabe and Daniel Fernández. The school’s new CLIMAVORE x Jameel at RCA partnership will focus on two projects which 'reimagine how we eat as human activity changes the climate by developing new methodologies and enhancing policies around the globe'. Both projects will offer research fellowship opportunities to postgraduate students while exploring 'how nature-centred food systems can be developed with communities in drylands and wetlands that are subject to particular seasonal stresses' in the form of site-specific case studies in Türkiye, France and Italy, respectively.
fieldData.name: Royal College of Art launches CLIMAVORE x Jameel partnership with Cooking Sections for unique sustainability research
fieldData.arabic-title: الكلية الملكية للفنون تطلق CLIMAVORE x جميل شراكة مع أقسام الطهي لأبحاث الاستدامة الفريدة
عزز الاقتصاد من خلال تقديم جراحة NHS الروتينية في عطلة نهاية الأسبوع - تقرير
fieldData.summary: As the British health service faces challenges overcoming a significant patient backlog, a new report by the Institute for Public Policy Research (IPPR) and LCP Health Analytics suggests that the NHS should offer routine pre-planned operations at the weekend to reduce the record waiting list and help boost the economy. Lord Darzi of Denham, advisory committee member, Community Jameel and consultant surgeon at Imperial College NHS Trust and the Royal Marsden NHS Foundation Trust agreed that the report highlights 'compelling policy levers' that policymakers can use to reduce the backlog and echoed arguments that there is both a convincing moral and economic case to 'go further and faster' in working through the NHS backlog of patients.
fieldData.name: Boost the economy by offering routine NHS surgery at the weekend | Report

fieldData.summary: As the World Bank undergoes a change in leadership and prepares to adapt its mission to address global warming, it should not only provide financial resources, but also enhance its ability to generate evidence-based solutions and bring them to policymakers’ attention. As a guiding example, research by Esther Duflo, co-founder and co-director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) in India pointed out that, contrary to common belief, India has some of the strictest environmental regulations in the world, but lacks the ability to enforce them. Duflo's team show how devising proper mechanisms to address weak state capacity, unreliable contract enforcement and institutional corruption can significantly improve emission outcomes. It is here, in the design and implementation of policies to address institutional shortcomings, that the World Bank could add enormous value, in addition to investing in renewable energy and other climate-friendly technologies.
fieldData.name: What the world bank can do about climate change
fieldData.arabic-title: ما يمكن أن يفعله البنك الدولي بشأن تغير المناخ

fieldData.summary: A team of researchers, advised by Professor Regina Barzilay at the Jameel Clinic, the epicentre of machine learning and health at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), has developed DiffDock, a molecular docking model that has the potential to discover new drugs faster than traditional methods and reduce the risk of adverse side effects. A paper introducing this groundbreaking model will be presented at the '11th International Conference on Learning Representations'. DiffDock's unique approach to computational drug design represents a paradigm shift from current state-of-the-art tools used by most pharmaceutical companies, presenting a significant opportunity for revolutionising the traditional drug development pipeline.
fieldData.name: Speeding up drug discovery with diffusion generative models
fieldData.arabic-title: تسريع اكتشاف الأدوية بنماذج منتشرة

fieldData.summary: As more people turn to chat-based AIs for medical advice, it remains to be seen how these tools stack up against—or could complement—human doctors. According to Marzyeh Ghassemi, a computer scientist at the Jameel Clinic, the epicentre of machine learning and health at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), while AI chatbots could be a valuable tool, they should not replace the expertise of trained medical professionals. In particular, Marzyeh highlights the lag of regulatory bodies to catch up with the pace of AI development and deployment, and is concerned that chatbots will perpetuate racism, sexism, and other types of prejudice that persist in medicine—and across the Internet.
fieldData.name: AI chatbots can diagnose medical conditions at home. How good are they?
fieldData.arabic-title: يمكن لروبوتات الدردشة التي تعمل بالذكاء الاصطناعي تشخيص الحالات الطبية في المنزل. كم هم جيدون؟

fieldData.summary: A global consortium of over 1,500 researchers and physicians, led by researchers at the Jameel Institute at Imperial College London, including principal investigator, Majid Ezzati, analysed the height and weight data of 71 million children and adolescents aged 5 to 19 years across urban and rural areas in 200 countries. Between 1990 and 2020 the study traced the development of children and adolescents, and found that the advantages of living in cities with regard to healthy growth had shrunk across the world. Published in Nature, the paper indicate that in 1990, school-aged children and adolescents who grew up in cities with opportunities for better education, nutrition, sports and recreation were a few inches taller and had higher BMI than their rural peers. By 2020, however, the BMI averages rose for most countries except sub-Saharan Africa and south Asia, where the BMI rose faster in rural areas.
fieldData.name: Living in cities is not necessarily beneficial for growth of children, study finds
fieldData.arabic-title: وجدت الدراسة أن العيش في المدن ليس بالضرورة مفيدًا لنمو الأطفال

fieldData.name: Rural kids in wealthy countries now grow taller than children in cities, study finds
fieldData.arabic-title: توصلت دراسة إلى أن أطفال الريف في البلدان الغنية أصبحوا الآن أطول من الأطفال في المدن
fieldData.summary: Some health benefits of urban living for children may be diminishing globally, particularly in affluent countries like the US, UK, and France, according to a study by the Jameel Institute at Imperial College London, led by scientist Majid Ezzati. The research, published in Nature, analysed trends in child and adolescent height and body mass index (BMI) across 200 countries from 1990 to 2020. Previous studies showed that urban areas provided better education, nutrition, and healthcare, resulting in taller children compared to rural areas in wealthy nations. However, the urban advantage has shrunk in the 21st century due to improvements in height for children in rural areas. Dr Ezzati emphasised that addressing growing inequalities, especially for the poor, through initiatives like supplementary incomes and free school meal programmes, is crucial regardless of whether children live in cities or rural areas.

Professor Edward Gregg, a leading population health scientist, has been awarded EUR 4.3 million from Science Foundation Ireland (SFI) to fund a new research centre at Royal College of Surgeons Ireland (RCSI). Formerly professor of diabetes and cardiovascular disease epidemiology and researcher at Jameel Institute, Imperial College London, Edward will lead a team of 13 new researchers to help reduce the burden of chronic diseases. Named Converge, the new centre will aim to transform the way population-level data and research platforms are deployed in Ireland to prevent and reduce the burden of chronic diseases such as diabetes and obesity. Researchers at the new centre will collaborate closely with the World Health Organisation, Imperial College London, the US Center for Disease Control and Prevention, Maynooth University, the University of Galway and the HSE.
fieldData.name: RCSI researcher awarded EUR 4.3 million to establish health research centre
fieldData.arabic-title: منح باحث RCSI 4.3 مليون يورو لإنشاء مركز للبحوث الصحية

fieldData.excerpt:
The great human and planetary issues of our time - from climate change to outbreaks of infectious disease - require collective human responses, with science at the core.

British science is world-leading in many fields, but in tackling these global challenges we need to work with researchers on the frontline if humanity is to succeed. This means opening pathways for international scientific collaboration, but it also means funding and supporting able scientists overseas with new equipment, training and financial resources for research.

For example, we need to support epidemiologists conducting surveillance work in communities with high risks of spillover of zoonotic viruses, like avian flu. We must empower scientists working in fragile coastal and dryland environments like Bangladesh and Kenya to monitor the early signs of impending crises caused by climate change. We have to share artificial intelligence tools with clinicians in rural, low-resource settings to detect cancer early, and to develop and refine those tools on the basis of their findings.
fieldData.summary: In his opinion piece for Comment Central, George Richards, Director, Community Jameel, emphasises the necessity for global scientific collaboration to address major issues like climate change and infectious diseases. He advocates for supporting international scientists with resources, training, and equipment. Partnerships, like those between Community Jameel and UK institutions, such the Jameel Institute at Imperial College London and the Jameel Observatory for Food Security Early Action at the University of Edinburgh, demonstrate the advancements possible through such collaboration. He urges the UK's new Secretary of State, Michelle Donelan, to prioritise funding for these international partnerships, highlighting their benefits for British science and the urgent need to address global threats.
fieldData.name: New Department for Science needs to drive breakthroughs in scientific research abroad too
fieldData.arabic-title: يحتاج القسم الجديد للعلوم إلى تحقيق اختراقات في البحث العلمي في الخارج أيضًا

fieldData.summary: The Sedona International Film Festival will join theatres around the world to present the world premiere of Paramount's ‘The journey: A music special from Andrea Bocelli’ showing 02-06 April 2023, at the Mary D Fisher Theatre. Andrea Bocelli partnered with Community Jameel in 2019 to launch the Andrea Bocelli Foundation-Community Jameel Scholarship at the Royal College of Music (RCM) in London, supporting talented musicians to attend the schools world-leading Opera Studio. In ‘The journey’, Andrea and his wife Veronica travel on horseback along Italy’s Via Francigena, an ancient road traveled by pilgrims for centuries in the footsteps of the apostles and saints. Along the way, they are joined by friends including 2019 Bocelli-Jameel scholar, Clara Barbier Serrano, as well as Michael W Smith, Tori Kelly, Tauren Wells and TAYA for world-class musical performances in some of Italy’s most magnificent venues and majestic locations.
fieldData.name: Fest presents ‘The journey: A music special from Andrea Bocelli’ April 2-6
fieldData.arabic-title: يقدم Fest الرحلة: عرض موسيقي خاص من Andrea Bocelli ، من 2 إلى 6 أبريل
fieldData.thumbnail-alt-text: Andrea Bocelli sits in a garden playing guitar.

fieldData.summary: The advantages of living in cities for children and adolescents’ healthy growth and development are shrinking across much of the world, according to a new global analysis of trends in child and adolescent height and body mass index (BMI) led by Imperial College London and published in Nature. The research, by a global consortium of more than 1500 researchers and physicians, including Majid Ezzati, research lead at Imperial's Jameel Institute, analysed the height and weight data from 71 million children and adolescents (aged 5 to 19 years) across urban and rural areas of 200 countries from 1990 to 2020.
fieldData.name: Diminishing health benefits of living in cities for children and teens
fieldData.arabic-title: تناقص الفوائد الصحية للعيش في المدن للأطفال والمراهقين

fieldData.summary: A new program, titled Leveraging Evaluation and Evidence for Equitable Recovery (LEVER), has been launched by the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) North America and Results for America, a nonprofit focused on helping policymakers use data and evidence effectively. LEVER aims to assist state and local leaders in using evaluation and evidence in their decision-making as they seek to promote economic mobility and racial equity in the aftermath of COVID-19. Vincent Quan, Co-executive Director of J-PAL North America, highlighted the importance of evaluation and evidence in sustaining economic recovery, but acknowledged the challenges in implementing evidence-based policies. Both Results for America and J-PAL North America, as experienced organizations in evidence-based policymaking, are committed to supporting jurisdictions at their current level of readiness in this endeavor.
fieldData.name: J-PAL North America and Results for America launch support for state and local leaders to evaluate programs using federal recovery dollars
fieldData.arabic-title: تطلق J-PAL أمريكا الشمالية ونتائج لأمريكا دعمًا لقادة الولايات والقادة المحليين لتقييم البرامج باستخدام دولارات الاسترداد الفيدرالية

fieldData.summary: The Royal College of Art (RCA) and Community Jameel launched CLIMAVORE x Jameel at RCA, a new initiative led by Alon Schwabe and Daniel Fernández Pascual, Senior Research Fellows in the RCA School of Architecture and co-founders of the art and architectural practice Cooking Sections. Based in the RCA’s School of Architecture, CLIMAVORE x Jameel at RCA uses architectural and artistic investigative tools, education and action to advance ecological networks beyond current understandings of sustainability, and produce new knowledge around food and climate justice. The new partnership aims to reimagine how we eat as human activity changes the climate by developing new methodologies and enhancing policies around the globe.
fieldData.name: Royal College of Art and Community Jameel announce CLIMAVORE partnership with Turner Prize nominees Cooking Sections
fieldData.arabic-title: تعلن الكلية الملكية للفنون والمجتمع جميل عن شراكة CLIMAVORE مع أقسام الطبخ المرشحين لجائزة تيرنر

fieldData.summary: Developed on the basis of the findings of a study by researchers at the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL), the ‘Urgent relief and just action' (Urja) desk concept was implemented in local police stations in the Indian state of Madhya Pradesh in 2017 to increase registration of cases of gender-based violence. Since its establishment, the initiative has provided ample space for women victims of violence to share their issues with the police, according to participants at a three-day conference on 'Justice, inclusion and victims' access' held in Bhopal, India.
fieldData.name: Bhopal: ‘Urja desk’ allows women to freely share issues with police
fieldData.arabic-title: بوبال: "Urja Desk" يسمح للمرأة بمشاركة القضايا بحرية مع الشرطة
وقتل الجفاف في الصومال العام الماضي 43 ألف شخص
fieldData.summary: For five wet seasons in a row, Somalis waited for rain while their crops withered, their cattle perished and many people died of hunger or disease. A new report, released by UN agencies and the Somali government, estimates that there were 43,000 “excess deaths” in the country last year. Now Somalis are waiting for signs of the “Gu” rains, which are due next month. A slightly improved forecast and a recent drop in food prices offer hope, but even when this drought finally ends it will take years for indebted families to restock their animals and assets. Governments and aid agencies should start planning for the next one by developing strategic water points and infrastructure, argues Guyo Roba, head of the Jameel Observatory in Kenya, an international research partnership in Nairobi. Too often, their focus fades when the emergency does. “Immediately we get a better season, we go back and sleep,” he says.
fieldData.name: Drought killed 43,000 people in Somalia last year

fieldData.summary: Three non-profit organisations with a proven record of local and regional support for emerging entrepreneurs are joining MIT's Jameel World Education Lab (J-WEL) network as its pilot innovation cohort. Member organisations benefit from J-WEL's curation of ideas, workshops, global linkage to like-minded educators, access to MIT resources, and collaboration, enabling them to better serve learners. Each new member is launching a programme under the heading of StartSmart, recognizing their expertise in their regions and prior collaborations with MIT. "StartSmart members are ready to inspire and equip entrepreneurially minded learners who will put what they learn to use within their communities. The careers they build, solutions they develop, and new businesses they create will benefit many," said Dr Anjali Sastry, faculty director of J-WEL.
fieldData.name: MIT Jameel World Education Lab welcomes three member organisations dedicated to helping aspiring innovators to start smart
fieldData.arabic-title: يرحب مختبر جميل العالمي للتعليم ومعهد ماساتشوستس للتكنولوجيا بثلاث منظمات أعضاء مكرسة لمساعدة المبتكرين الطموحين على البدء بذكاء

fieldData.summary: The Climavore project, curated by Turner prize nominees Daniel Fernández Pascual and Alon Schwabe, known as Cooking Sections, has partnered with cultural institutions such as Tate and the Serpentine since its launch in 2020. Now, it arrives at the Palazzo delle Esposizioni, with ingredients and recipes designed to raise public awareness of the impact of food production and consumption. Climavore's arrival at the Palazzo heralds the launch of the duo's new research initiative, Climavore x Jameel at the Royal College of Arts (RCA) in London. Based in the RCA’s School of Architecture, CLIMAVORE x Jameel at RCA aims to reimagine how we eat as human activity changes the climate by developing new methodologies and enhancing policies around the globe.
fieldData.name: Al Palazzo delle Esposizioni, nel menu di "Climavore" c'è l'ambiente
fieldData.arabic-title: في Palazzo delle Esposizioni ، تشمل قائمة "Climavore" البيئة

fieldData.summary: How can we ensure that students from all backgrounds can achieve their academic potential? In the first of a series of blog posts exploring the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab's (J-PAL's) research and activities across Europe, Cillian Nolan, Director of policy at J-PAL Europe, looks at a series of randomised evaluations in Italy that explore this question with a particular focus on students from immigrant families. As school systems across Europe welcome increasingly diverse populations, this research provides insights into pathways for transforming students’ educational aspirations and academic performance, as well as their well-being.
fieldData.name: J-PAL at 20: Promoting more inclusive education in Italy
fieldData.arabic-title: J-PAL في الساعة 20: تشجيع المزيد من التعليم الشامل في إيطاليا

fieldData.summary: First identified in 1961, mRNA therapies are nothing new, and researchers have been trying to master targeted treatments using mRNA for decades. Now, scientist Jim Collins, Faculty lead at MIT Jameel Clinic, and his colleagues at Harvard Wyss Institute believe they're on the cusp of the next stage with the development of a novel engineered RNA sense-and-respond circuit named Detection and Amplification of RNA Triggers via ADAR (DART VADAR), which seeks out a specific molecular marker of disease for highly specialized treatment. DART VADAR works by detecting small amounts of RNA molecules of target interest within a given sample, even when mixed with larger amounts of other RNA molecules. The development could have important applications in medical diagnosis and treatment, allowing early disease detection. The technology is still in its early stages of development, but Jim Collins and his colleagues are optimistic about its potential.
fieldData.name: DART VADAR alters the deal for precision RNA-based therapies
fieldData.arabic-title: DART VADAR يغير الصفقة للحصول على علاجات دقيقة تعتمد على الحمض النووي الريبي

fieldData.summary: While USD 122 billion in federal funding for education under the 'American rescue plan act' is a step in the right direction, policy experts argue it is not enough to help students catch up after the COVID-19 pandemic. Vincent Quan, Co-executive director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) North America, emphasises the need for targeted interventions that address the specific needs of students. Quan suggests that the federal funding should be used to support research and pilot programmes that can be scaled up to benefit more students, and argues that ongoing policy evaluations are necessary to ensure that the interventions are effective and that resources are being used efficiently.
fieldData.name: Opinion: New federal funding alone won’t be enough to help students catch up in the classroom post pandemic
fieldData.arabic-title: الرأي: لن يكون التمويل الفيدرالي الجديد وحده كافيًا لمساعدة الطلاب على اللحاق بالفصل الدراسي بعد الوباء
براك الدولية توقع مذكرة تفاهم مع رواندا لتمكين الأشخاص الذين يعيشون في فقر مدقع
fieldData.summary: BRAC International, a leading nonprofit organisation empowering communities in poverty, signed a memorandum of understanding (MoU) with Rwanda's Ministry of Local Government to empower the estimated half of the local population that still lives in extreme poverty. Efforts include extending BRAC's model Graduation programme to Rwanda and supporting participants' health, training, financial literacy and social empowerment. Research by Abhijit Banerjee and Esther Duflo, co-founders of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab, proves that this combination of support and resources is critical for long-term impact.
fieldData.name: BRAC International signs MoU with Rwanda to empower people in extreme poverty

fieldData.arabic-title: يستخدم DART VADAR قوة الإنزيمات لتحسين عقاقير الحمض النووي الريبي
fieldData.name: DART VADAR harnesses the force of enzymes for better RNA drugs
fieldData.summary: For decades, researchers have faced challenges in developing RNA-based therapies for diseases that only affect a single organ or cell type, wherein the full-body immune response caused by mRNA vaccines is not necessary to combat the disease. Researchers at MIT and Wyss Institute at Harvard University, including Jim Collins, Faculty lead at MIT Jameel Clinic, have developed a new system to overcome this roadblock called DART VADAR, which uses an enzyme that edits RNA in the human body to trigger the translation of a genetic payload in response to the presence of a specific molecular marker of disease and/or cell type. The technology has the potential to enable the development of highly specific treatments for a variety of diseases. The study was reported in Nature Communications.

On World Water Day, the Abdul Latif Jameel Water and Food Systems Lab (J-WAFS) hosted a student presentation from PhD students Gokul Sampath, who is researching safe water access and quality in rural India, Carolyn Sheline, who works alongside J-WAFS principal investigator Amos Winter, and Jonathan Bessette, a mechanical engineering PhD student working on desalination. Carolyn presented her low-cost and water- and energy-efficient drip irrigation system for farmers in the Middle East and Africa that can help protect their limited supply of freshwater. Her project won first place in the 2020 J-WAFS World Food Day Video Competition.
fieldData.name: J-WAFS students come together for World Water Day event
fieldData.arabic-title: طلاب J-WAFS يجتمعون معًا في فعالية يوم المياه العالمي
تقدم الصور التفصيلية من الفضاء صورة أوضح لتأثيرات الجفاف على النباتات
fieldData.summary: Globally, drought is devastating vegetation and severely stressing water supplies, compromising food production and spiking food insecurity. Abdul Latif Jameel Water and Food Systems Lab (J-WAFS) researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), César Terrer and Wenzhe Jiao, are using remote sensing observations to build high-resolution systems to monitor drought, which can offer fundamental information on drought location, frequency and severity. In 2022, Terrer, assistant professor in MIT's department of civil and environmental engineering, received J-WAFS seed grant funding to produce drought monitoring systems for farmers.
fieldData.name: Detailed images from space offer clearer picture of drought effects on plants

fieldData.summary: Flavio Emilio Vila Skrzypek, a graduate student in the department of urban studies and planning at MIT, wants to design cities without inequities. Ultimately, he hopes to use his master’s degree to contribute to the decolonisation of land and property regimes in his home country, Peru. Flavio worked with his advisor, Abdul Latif Jameel Water and Food Systems Lab (J-WAFS) principal investigator and associate professor in the department of urban studies and planning, Gabriella Carolini, on a J-WAFS project to enhance US water affordability.
fieldData.name: Designing for better lives
fieldData.arabic-title: تصميم لحياة أفضل

fieldData.name: New funding models crucial to driving climate adaptation efforts
fieldData.arabic-title: نماذج تمويل جديدة ضرورية لدفع جهود التكيف مع المناخ
fieldData.summary: The global health sector must pilot innovative funding models to secure the financing needed to mitigate climate crisis, drive new adaptation strategies and protect gains made in disease elimination, participants said at the Forecasting Healthy Futures Global Summit in Abu Dhabi. Participants, including Uzma Sulaiman, associate director of Community Jameel and Tala Al Ramahi, a director at Reaching the Last Mile, a portfolio of global health programs driven by the private commitment of His Highness Sheikh Mohamed bin Zayed Al Nahyan, President of the UAE, emphasised the role philanthropy can play in providing venture funding to test novel approaches and seed innovation. The summit saw His Excellency Majid Al-Suwaidi, Director general of COP28, pledge that health would be a central focus at the upcoming COP, also in Dubai.

Bocelli-Jameel Scholar Seonwoo Lee's played The Fire in Ravel's 'L’enfant et les sortilèges' as part of the Royal College of Music's spring opera double bill. Seonwoo also performed as the Blue Fairy in Respighi's 'La bella dormente nel bosco'. Seonwoo is the 2022 recipient of the Andrea Bocelli Foundation-Community Jameel Scholarship at the Royal College of Music (RCM). Launched in 2019, the scholarship is awarded to talented musicians chosen both on a merit assessed at audition and their need for support to overcome barriers and access world-class training at the RCM's Opera Studio.
fieldData.name: A ‘fantastic’ Respighi-Ravel double bill at the Royal College of Music
fieldData.arabic-title: فاتورة مزدوجة "رائعة" لـ Respighi-Ravel في الكلية الملكية للموسيقى
في القاهرة قصر تظهر فيه طبقات التاريخ
fieldData.summary: A couple has restored and reimagined a nearly decimated 15th century palace in Cairo's historic neighbourhood, al-Darb al-Ahmar, as a home and a cultural hub, revealing the complexity of the city’s past. Eleven years after the project began, the house, named Beit Yakan, opened this past June as a rare books library focusing on architecture, as well as a cultural centre that hosts workshops and courses in traditional Egyptian crafts in collaboration with local organisations including the Jameel House of Traditional Arts.
fieldData.name: In Cairo, a mansion where the layers of history show through

fieldData.summary:
The Simon Fraser University (SFU) has announced its 2023 honorary degree recipients, which include Esther Duflo, co-founder and co-director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Esther was recognised for her groundbreaking research on global poverty and her experimental approach in designing and testing solutions to social problems. Her work has helped to identify effective interventions in areas such as education, healthcare and poverty alleviation. The honorary degree recognises Esther's significant contributions to the field of economics and her commitment to making a positive impact on the world. Other recipients of the SFU honorary degree include Indigenous rights advocate Cindy Blackstock, artist Ai Weiwei and neuroscientist Molly Crockett.

‍
fieldData.name: Simon Fraser University announces 2023 honorary degree recipients
fieldData.arabic-title: تعلن جامعة سيمون فريزر عن الفائزين بالدرجات الفخرية لعام 2023

fieldData.summary: Too much emphasis on the bigger picture can distract from the pragmatic and small base-level things that are critical to achieving larger missions. 'Thinking small' is a core finding of the economic research of co-founders and co-directors of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) and Nobel laureates Abhijit Banerjee and Esther Duflo. In their book, 'Poor economics' (2011) the authors warn against “Talking about the problems of the world without talking about accessible solutions”. Instead of imposing a grand solution on an enormous problem, they advocate for making small changes that can add up to a pragmatic solution.
fieldData.name: Power of thinking ‘small’: How small changes drive the big picture
fieldData.arabic-title: قوة التفكير "الصغيرة": كيف تقود التغييرات الصغيرة الصورة الكبيرة

fieldData.summary: Kim Dadisman, associate director of policy at the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) North America and Laina Sonterblum, senior policy associate at J-PAL North America, explore how tutoring programmes can be an effective tool in combatting learning loss and supplementing curriculums in schools in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic. In the United States, the Biden administration has publicly called on districts to spend COVID-relief dollars on tutoring. In the United Kingdom, the Department for Education launched the national tutoring programme. These initiatives are excellent steps toward learning recovery, but could fall short of their potential if implementation strays too far from the evidence. Evidence from rigorous evaluations of nearly 100 tutoring programmes demonstrated that tutoring consistently had large, positive impacts on student learning. That said, not all programmes are equally effective.
fieldData.name: Tutoring works on paper, how about in practice?​
fieldData.arabic-title: الدروس الخصوصية تعمل على الورق ، ماذا عن الممارسة العملية؟

fieldData.summary: Co-scientific director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) North America, Amy Finkelstein, was selected in STAT's 2023 STATUS List, an annual list world leaders in life sciences. Amy is recognised for conducting randomised control trials investigating health economics debates. In 2022, papers authored or co-authored by Amy showed that rates of opioid addiction could best be lowered by policies targeting regional variations in doctors’ willingness to prescribe the drugs and that an American’s risk of dying during the COVID-19 pandemic depended less on location than on racial or ethnic group, education level, and job sector.
fieldData.name: J-PAL co-scientific director Amy Finkelstein recognised in 2023 STATUS List as a leader in life sciences
fieldData.arabic-title: تم الاعتراف بإيمي فينكلشتاين التابعة لـ J-PAL في قائمة الحالة لعام 2023 كشركة رائدة في علوم الحياة

fieldData.summary:
'The journey with Andrea Bocelli' follows the maestro as he travels Italy’s Via Francigena on horseback to rediscover some of life’s greatest joys. Throughout the spiritual pilgrimage along the ancient trail, Andrea reflects on life’s biggest questions with friends and family, and performs with talented artists, including: Clara Barbier Serrano, the 2020 winner of the Andrea Bocelli Foundation-Community Jameel Scholarship, Katherine Jenkins, Matteo Bocelli, Michael W. Smith, Ramin Bahrami, Tauren Wells, TAYA and Tori Kelly.

‍
fieldData.name: Embark on a musical travel journey as Andrea Bocelli arrives today on Paramount+
fieldData.arabic-title: انطلق في رحلة سفر موسيقية مع وصول "أندريا بوتشيلي" اليوم على قناة + Paramount

fieldData.summary: Homelessness in the United States is a pressing issue that requires increased research on effective strategies to address it and foster long-term housing stability. With grant funding from Google.org—Google’s philanthropic arm—the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) North America's Bay Area Evaluation (BAE) Incubator supported Bay Area service providers with implementing and evaluating cash transfer programmes to assess their impact on homelessness and housing stability. J-PAL North America’s Evaluation Incubators build the base of rigorous evidence by supporting organizations and government agencies to transform their research questions into comprehensive evaluation designs. The model provides selected partners with funding, technical assistance and training on evaluation design, and connections to J-PAL’s network of expert researchers.
fieldData.name: BAE Incubator partner series, part five: Seeking systems-level change to address housing instability
fieldData.arabic-title: سلسلة شركاء BAE Incubator ، الجزء الخامس: السعي لتغيير مستوى الأنظمة لمعالجة عدم استقرار الإسكان

fieldData.summary: Bocelli-Jameel Scholar Seonwoo Lee performed in the Royal College of Music (RCM) spring opera double bill as the Blue Fairy in Respighi’s 'La bella dormente nel bosco' and The Fire in Ravel’s 'L’entant et les sortilèges'. A soprano from South Korea, Seonwoo is the 2022 recipient of the Andrea Bocelli Foundation-Community Jameel Scholarship at RCM. Since its launch in 2019, the scholarship supports students to study full-time at the RCM's Opera Studio in London, one of the world’s leading conservatoires for the performing arts.
fieldData.name: Bocelli-Jameel Scholar Seonwoo Lee performs in Royal College Of Music opera double bill
fieldData.arabic-title: الباحث العلمي من بوتشيلي-جميل ، سيونو لي ، يؤدي في أوبرا الكلية الملكية للموسيقى فاتورة مزدوجة

fieldData.summary:
Why is dental insurance so crummy? Why is pet insurance so expensive? Why does your car insurer ask for your credit score? The answer to these questions lies in understanding how insurance works. The authors of 'Risky Business', Amy Finkelstein, co-sceintific director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) North America, Liran Einav and Ray Fisman explore why insurers want to know so much about us and whether we should let them obtain this information.

‍
fieldData.name: Why insurance markets are a game of cat and mouse
fieldData.arabic-title: لماذا أسواق التأمين هي لعبة القط والفأر

fieldData.summary:
As part of its International Women's Day activities, the Egyptian Food Bank hosted a panel addressing 'The role of women in achieving food security in Egyptian society' to highlight the causes and repercussions of women's food insecurity. The session focused on the organisation's strategy to support women's food security through specialised programmes, policy proposals and partnership with scientific foundations, and was attended by representatives from the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL), the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation, the United Nations Children's Fund, the United Nations Women and the National Research Centre.

‍
fieldData.name: Egyptian Food Bank: Addressing the causes and repercussions of women's food insecurity
fieldData.arabic-title: جلسة نقاشية لبنك الطعام المصري لمناقشة تداعيات انعدام الأمن الغذائي لدى المرأة

fieldData.summary:
Debunking the myth that cash transfer programmes render recipients “lazy”, co-founder and co-director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) and 2019 Nobel laureate in economics Abhijit Banerjee endorsed such welfare schemes for helping to combat poverty and inequality. Delivering a keynote address on the theme 'How to fight poverty? Kerala, India and the world', Abhijit, who co-authored a paper analysing data from randomised controlled trials of cash transfer programmes in 13 countries, opined the criticism that cash transfers render the poor "lazy" is the “starting point” in the neoliberal thinking about poverty.

‍
fieldData.name: Easy money does not create a lazy poor: Abhijit Banerjee
fieldData.arabic-title: المال السهل لا يخلق فقيرًا كسولًا: أبهيجيت بانيرجي

fieldData.summary: Jameel Institute epidemiologist at Imperial College London Dr Anne Cori has been awarded a share of this year's Adam's Prize for her outstanding work in modelling infectious disease outbreaks. Awarded annually by the University of Cambridge to UK-based researchers carrying out international research in the mathematical sciences, Anne is the sixth woman to win the prize in its almost 175-year history. Former winners include theoretical physicist professor Stephen Hawking (1966) and the 2023 prize is awarded for achievements in the field of mathematical and statistical epidemiology, a first since it was first awarded in 1850.
fieldData.name: Infectious disease modeller wins prestigious mathematics prize
fieldData.arabic-title: مصمم نماذج الأمراض المعدية يفوز بجائزة الرياضيات المرموقة

fieldData.summary: As Malaysia's research and development expenditure lags behind that of major Asian economies, Minister of Higher Education, Datuk Seri Mohamed Khaled Nordin, dedicated his inaugural speech to highlighting the need for Malaysia to prioritise impactful research that can bring real benefits to society. He called for greater funding for applied research, pointing to Esther Duflo, co-founder and co-director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL), whose work applies research to tackle poverty, education and health issues.
fieldData.name: Research needs to produce beneficial impact to the society and nation
fieldData.arabic-title: يحتاج البحث إلى إحداث تأثير مفيد على المجتمع والأمة

fieldData.summary: The World Health Organisation's first-ever major initiative linking arts and public health, the Jameel Arts & Health Lab aims to amplify research on the impact of the arts on health and wellbeing. The lab's ultimate aim is to inform policy across 193 UN member states and scale up effective arts-in-health interventions around the world to improve the health and well-being of millions of people, particularly among overlooked and underserved communities, and including in post-conflict recovery contexts.
fieldData.name: New international laboratory aims to study and promote health benefits of arts activities for individuals and communities
fieldData.arabic-title: يهدف المختبر الدولي الجديد إلى دراسة وتعزيز الفوائد الصحية للأنشطة الفنية للأفراد والمجتمعات

fieldData.summary: There is a growing movement to apply randomised trials not just in healthcare but in other things government does. Overseas development is perhaps the most advanced example. The results of trials run by the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL), for example, have deeply influenced how the UK government spends aid money. Applying scientific rigour to government programmes seems unobjectionable, especially in a world of fake news and backfiring populist policies. So why hasn’t it taken off faster?
fieldData.name: The big idea: Should governments run more experiments?
fieldData.arabic-title: الفكرة الكبيرة: هل يجب على الحكومات إجراء المزيد من التجارب؟

fieldData.summary:
The Chicago Booth executive education programme aims to develop innovative and proactive leaders with the necessary skills to enhance the efficiency of their institutions and navigate market changes. The programme is part of the Ministry's wider partnership with the Sawiris Foundation for Social Development focused on employment and development, and also includes initiatives with the Egypt Impact Lab at the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab Middle East and North Africa at the American University in Cairo.

fieldData.summary: The UK-based Nigerian artist focuses on therapeutic art projects, with a specific emphasis on improving health and health-related outcomes. In 2013, Kunle founded Tender Arts Nigeria, a social enterprise focused on therapeutic arts, art education and civic engagement. Established by the WHO Regional Office for Europe, Steinhardt School at New York University, Community Jameel and CULTURUNNERS, the Jameel Arts & Health Lab highlights research to promote the broad integration of the arts into mainstream care.

fieldData.summary: The World Economic Forum's monthly round-up highlights some of the key artificial intelligence (AI) stories from the past four weeks. This month's edition includes: 'MIT Jameel Clinic-developed AI model, Sybil, set to improve cancer detection and transplant surgery', 'Romanian government reveals AI sentiment adviser', 'US rejects copyright for AI-generated images' and 'Let AI take the strain when it comes to doing the housework'.
fieldData.name: Six things you need to know about AI this month
fieldData.arabic-title: 6 أشياء يجب أن تعرفها عن الذكاء الاصطناعي هذا الشهر

fieldData.summary: According to the latest Multiple Indicator Survey (MIS) report of the Indian government’s National Sample Survey Office (NSSO), 15.4% of young men aged between 15 and 29 are not engaged in either education, employment or training (NEET), compared to 51.7% of young women. Economist and author Lekha Chakraborty, a professor at the National Institute of Public Finance and Policy, cited the prevalence of early marriage as one of the main drivers of this gender skew, and based her view on a 2013 study by co-founder and co-director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL), Abhijit Banerjee and his colleagues, which highlighted how marriage is an economic decision for many women in India, one that their families often consider a wiser investment than education or training. Addressing these challenges requires a multi-pronged policy approach to change societal attitudes towards women's education and work, and to empower women to make their own choices about their education.
fieldData.name: 33% of India’s youth aren’t in employment, education, or training. Most of them are women
fieldData.arabic-title: 33٪ من شباب الهند ليسوا في وظائف أو تعليم أو تدريب. معظمهم من النساء

fieldData.summary: About five years ago, instead of sending rice bags directly to villages for distribution to the poor, the Indonesian government sent debit cards to buy the equivalent amount of food at local neighbourhood shops. Suddenly, millions of Indonesians in the programme started receiving the total amount of food intended for them 81 percent of the time, according to a randomised control study that MIT economists, including Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Actions Lab (J-PAL) co-founder and co-director, Abhijit Banerjee, helped lead.
fieldData.name: How debit cards helped Indonesia’s poor get more food
fieldData.arabic-title: كيف ساعدت بطاقات الخصم فقراء إندونيسيا في الحصول على المزيد من الطعام

fieldData.summary: The Jameel Arts & Health Lab, launched in New York is a result of agreements between the World Health Organization, the Steinhardt School at New York University, Community Jameel and CULTURUNNERS to “amplify scientific research into the effectiveness of the arts in improving health and wellbeing”. Projects include an impact assessment of the Yazidi Cultural Archives, launched last year on the United Nations’ Google Arts and Culture platform, which was curated by Yazidi survivors of the 2014 Da'esh genocide in Northern Iraq.
fieldData.name: Jameel Arts & Health Lab launched in in New York to examine role of arts in health and wellbeing

fieldData.summary: Soprano Laura Mekhail is the first Arab to be awarded the Andrea Bocelli Foundation-Community Jameel Scholarship. Established in 2019 in partnership with the Andrea Bocelli Foundation and Community Jameel, the scholarship supports new operatic talent to study full-time at the Royal College of Music, London. Since commencing her studies, the Egyptian-born soprano has performed alongside Bocelli himself at Maraya concert hall in AlUla, Saudi Arabia and recently gave a solo performance at Hayy Jameel in Jeddah.
fieldData.name: YUNG speaks to Egyptian soprano Laura Mekhail

fieldData.summary: Launched by World Health Organisation (WHO) Regional Office for Europe, the Steinhardt School at New York University (NYU), Community Jameel and CULTURUNNERS, the Jameel Arts & Health Lab represents the first major arts and health initiative in WHO history to drive policy change across 193 UN member states. Fady Jameel, vice chairman of Community Jameel said the lab will "leverage research to advance the integration of the arts into mainstream care and improve the health and wellbeing of millions of people across the world".
fieldData.name: Jameel Arts & Health Lab launched to measure the impact of the arts on health

fieldData.summary: Launched in 2020 by theMassachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) school of engineering and Takeda Pharamceuticals, the MIT-Takeda Programme leverages the experience of both entities to solve problems at the intersection of healthcare, medicine and artificial intelligence (AI). In its fourth year, the programme supports 10 teams in its second round of projects which span bio-pharmacy, from drug development to commercial and manufacturing. The MIT-Takeda Programme is part of the Abdul Latif Jameel Clinic for Machine Learning in Health.
fieldData.name: MIT-Takeda Programme heads into fourth year with crop of 10 new projects

fieldData.summary: Since Brexit, the UK has had to source fruit and vegetables from further afield, including Morocco where climate events are more prevalent. Several supermarkets have been forced to place limits on fruit and vegetable purchases. Scientists, including Guyo Roba of the Jameel Observatory, have warned that the climate crisis could jeopardise the world’s food security, by contributing to drought and unsurvivable conditions for crops, but the UK could ‘hit a tipping point’, warns NFU deputy president Tom Bradshaw.
fieldData.name: UK must prioritise food security warns NFU
fieldData.arabic-title: يجب على المملكة المتحدة إعطاء الأولوية للأمن الغذائي يحذر NFU

fieldData.summary:
At the India Today Conclave 2013, Banerjee, co-founder and co-director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab, shared his views on the flaws in government policymaking, the pros and cons of subsidies and narratives about the poor. Banerjee reminded audiences that the poor "are not just victims, they have a sense of what they want, the life they want. Every time we make policies, we forget that they have ambitions, aspirations. They are not zombies".

‍
fieldData.name: The poor are not zombies, they have aspirations: Economist Abhijit Banerjee
fieldData.arabic-title: الفقراء ليسوا زومبيًا ، لديهم تطلعات: الخبير الاقتصادي أبهيجيت بانيرجي
يحظر مولد الصور بالذكاء الاصطناعي Midjourney المواد الإباحية عن طريق حظر الكلمات المتعلقة بالجهاز التناسلي البشري
fieldData.summary: Midjourney, an AI-powered image generator, has been criticized for banning words related to the human reproductive system in an attempt to block pornographic content. Marzyeh Ghassemi, a principal investigator in MIT Jameel Clinic and assistant professor at the University of Toronto, believes that this approach is misguided and may even exacerbate existing inequalities. She argues that algorithms like Midjourney are only as unbiased as the data they are trained on. If the training data contains biases, then the algorithm will replicate those biases in its outputs. Marzyeh leads the Healthy Machine Learning Lab at MIT.
fieldData.name: AI image generator Midjourney blocks porn by banning words about the human reproductive system

fieldData.arabic-title: الشبكات العصبية لاكتشاف وتصميم الأدوية
fieldData.summary: Drugs play a central role in modern medicine, but bringing new ones to market is a lengthy, expensive process. Industry and academia are exploring ways to streamline the complex drug development pipeline with artificial intelligence (AI). However, efficiently analysing chemistry and biology have favoured neural networks, whose structure naturally mimics that of molecules. Regina Barzilay, executive director of MIT Jameel Clinic, the epicentre of AI and health at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, predicts that neural networks is an area "that's going to grow for the field, and we will see a lot of computer science discoveries along the way".
fieldData.name: Neural networks for drug discovery and design

fieldData.summary: The COVID-19 pandemic brought about federal policies that provided benefits for health, nutrition and food security for many US citizens. As the pandemic recedes, these policies are also coming to an end. Vincent Quan, co-executive director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) North America, emphasises the importance of food security remaining a federal policy priority. In addition to making some pandemic-era policies permanent, Vincent suggests investments in programmes that support local agriculture, increasing access to healthy foods in underserved areas and expanding nutrition education programmes. By taking these steps, he argues, states can help ensure that individuals and families have access to the resources they need to maintain healthy diets.
fieldData.name: How states can promote food security as the public health emergency ends
fieldData.arabic-title: كيف يمكن للدول تعزيز الأمن الغذائي مع انتهاء حالة الطوارئ الصحية العامة
معالجة البذور المزيفة بملصقات "غير قابلة للتقسيم"
fieldData.summary: The trade of counterfeit seeds can lead to significant agricultural losses and economic damage. MIT researchers, including principal investigator at the Abdul Latif Jameel Water and Food Systems Lab (J-WAFS), Benedetto Marelli, are working to develop "unclonable" labels that can distinguish authentic seeds from fake ones. Marelli and colleagues developed a technique to print labels that use multiple layers of inks with varying optical properties, making them difficult to replicate. The labels can be read using an application and have the potential to revolutionise seed authentication and traceability. Marelli's research projects, including those funded by J-WAFS, have developed new technologies to minimise food waste, enable agriculture in marginal lands, rapidly detect food contamination and precisely deliver payloads in plants.
fieldData.name: Tackling counterfeit seeds with “unclonable” labels

fieldData.summary: Partners inaugurated the first ever Ejada National Survey of Teachers' Wellbeing in Jordan. Yet, as AI takes on an increasingly wide scope and executes more functions, serious conversations are required about how AI will be deployed and affect social interactions, human life and even security.

Elena Sobrino, a student in the Abdul Latif Jameel Water and Food Systems Lab (J-WAFS) community and a PhD candidate in MIT’s history, anthropology, science, technology and society programme, explained the water toxicity crisis in Flint, Michigan, at an MIT Visual Arts Center event. The removal of carbon dioxide and re-injection of alkaline water could slowly start to reverse, at least locally, the acidification of the oceans, which in turn has threatened coral reefs and shellfish.

Community Jameel associate director Uzma Sulaiman said the data collected by the project will help build a better understanding of climate change's impact on marine life.

Seven researchers, including MIT Jameel Clinic faculty lead for artificial intelligence Professor Regina Barzilay and HM King Bhumibol Professor of Hydrology and Climate and Community Jameel advisory committee member Elfatih Eltahir were elected to the National Academy of Engineering for significant contributions to engineering research, practice and education, along with Markus Buehler, Neil Gershenfeld, David Simchi-Levi, David Miller, and Roger Kamm.

fieldData.summary: As part of Imperial’s new relationship with the UN Economic and Social Council (ECOSOC), the Global Development Hub held an event with the ECOSOC partnership forum about upscaling partnerships during the global recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. Professor Katharina Hauck, deputy director of the Jameel Institute, presented the DAEDALUS model developed at the Jameel Institute, which played a vital role in advising policymakers in a Southeast Asian lower-middle income country to extend its national lockdown as opposed to reopening the economy.
